content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												This is merely just a spin-off Ace Combat with some elements featured such as Close Range Assault (DFM and ASM) that mostly obligatory thus kinda ruins the freedom of the dogfight, aircraft usage restrictions on several missions, and the lack of the emphasized drama appeared on past titles (most of those featured superb anime-styled storylines that distinguish Ace Combat from most of other combat flight series ) makes it very detached from the entire series. The good thing about this that it has good graphics, sounds, and still fun gameplay even though some features mentioned above kinda ruins it. The flight dynamics are good for the game of this genre. It also has a fair amount of playable aircrafts to choose. Since I've played most of Ace Combat games in the series before, I found this one kinda disappointing if compared to the other titles in the series, but still enjoyable. Still, I personally think it's a good thing there's an Ace Combat game on PC officially (although the spin-off one) remembering there haven't been any Ace Combat games on PC officially before. Maybe someday there'll be another Ace Combat game on PC that will remain faithful to its Strangereal saga.In general, I'd still recommend this to those who enjoy arcade combat flight genre in general. But if you're an avid Ace Combat fan who trully miss and wants the iconic Strangereal elements in terms of story, atmosphere, and gameplay-feels from AC1,2,3,04,5,Zero, X, and 6, then maybe this game isn't for you.

												I wouldn't recommend this game if you are a hardcore Ace Combat fans. The gameplay is somewhat different from the usual Ace Combat series. The control have so much assist, even if you used the original mode and turn off all assist, it still have Dog Fight Mode and Air Strike Mode which is an automatic version of dogfight and air strike, all you have to do is fire a missile. I've played Ace Combat Assault Horizon on my Xbox 360 for many hours, and still kinda have a love-hate relationship with it.I like the little details they put in the game, like the missile warning, it featured a different language and voices depend on your aircraft like French, Swedish, English or Russian. The HUD is so minimalistic and didn't feature a damage percentage. If you have taken a damage, just fly around until your aircraft is recovered. It also featured a skin editor, so you can edit your aircraft color schemes and even your missiles smoke.If you want this game just wait until it's on discount. It does features all DLCs from the consoles version, although they remove the Tornado in the PC version because of license issue. You can also fly a helicopter and do a barrel roll with it to evade a missile, and there's one mission that let you play as a gun operator on AC-130, not so much Ace Combat.I only recommended it because you can take photos of your favorite aircraft using the Replay feature and screenshot it in action. And I got it from HumbleBundle for $1.

In case you're still thinking about it, here's more. For a PC title, I would expect these to be a given.. they are not: AWFUL peripheral/joystick support, no TrackIR... Trust me, I tried desperately to find some redeeming value in this title.. I thought, "Well, if it's awful, maybe being able to use my peripheral w/ Ace Combat (childhood dream come true!) would make it worth it." Forget it. This game should be burned at the stake. P.S. Folks... Medal of Honor did a better job (much better really) with an Apache.. and that's SAD!Do yourself a favor, pretend Ace Combat died peacefully in it's sleep with the previous title. If you're looking for just some fun arcade-themed aerial shenanigans, I don't know what to tell you. If you're looking for excellent graphics, realism, and peripheral support... it's time to come over to DCS. Cheers!

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												The Ace Combat series was for a long time my favorite series in the genre of Jet combat, and in many cases its the only series in the flight genre that has tried to find a nice balance between gameplay and realism. Ever since I first picked up and played Ace Combat 4 on the playstation 2 I have always been a fan of what ever project aces has done even though most of the titles in the playstion 2 and even 3 were very similar and really didn't bring anything new to the table, the past Ace Series titles and always gotten the most important platormer basics down. Fun combat, decent story telling, and a large variety of weapons, paint jobs, and fighters to trade missles with. While air to ground combat was never impressive, this never was the center of attention for fans of the series such as myself. Fun intense dogfights should always be the main focus in a series that has always been about jet on jet combat.Ace Combat Assault Horizon is clearly an attempt by Namco and Project Aces to mix things up a bit and try to add and improve on the genre and for that goal in mind I applaud them for attempting to bring something new and fun to a genre that has not seen any real changes to gameplay other than improved graphics. The introduction of Helicopters, and gunships and the new dogfight mechanics were very intresting ideas, and since we have been in the middle of the summer video game drought I figured I would give this title a spin for nastagia's sake and see if the new game features were as fun as the trailers looked.While I like the idea of the Dogfight mode and while it even looks pretty, the controls seem odd, clunky and poorly designed. Graphically stunning but it felt like it was to scripted at times and not natural. Helicopters were a huge disappointment. The machincs are almost outright broken and while it isn't always fair to compare titles I was hoping for gameplay closer to the feel of the Battlefield series of games. Overall I want to like this game but its cluncky controls prevent me from being able to recommend the title.

												So, here I am, at the end of the game so I can finally write a review. I still haven't beaten it, but i'll get to that in a second. I love the Ace Combat games. I played many of the other Ace Combat games and this one remains fairly true to the series. I don't care much for the helicopter scenes, but the AC-130 and B2 missions are pretty cool. The graphics are fine and the gameplay itself is good.....overall.So, why a negative review? Because of DFM, dog fighting mode. The concept itself is a neat idea, but it doesn't work in reality. But is something like that really worth a negative review?Spoiler*****Yes, god yes, it is so worth a negative review. At the end of the game you must fight a boss who is invincible. Not invincible hard, LITERALLY invincible. Missles LITTERALLY appear out of thin air and start flying at you in AND out of DFM while you try to shoot the boss down. It's a timed event and it's stupid. I don't know how many times I have repeated the final mission just to try and kill the final boss, but I end up dying just before the end of my timed invincible boss event. I'm giving it a negative review solely because of this right here. This moment is one of the most frustrating in gaming I have ever played and I don't know that I will ever have the patience to beat the final boss.

												Not much like the Ace Combat I know and love from Playstation and Playstation 2, too cinematic, action not super-tight like in those console games.  Yeah I know, I'm playing on a PC which isn't really optimized for games the way that a console is, but I'm okay with turning down the graphics settings until its barely more than blocky polygons but the game just won't let me go that low.  I think this game tries too hard to be like some other games like call of duty where you have a bomber gunning stage and a helicopter stage, while forgetting what made this series so great: the epic dogfights.  I think they also messed up the controls, seems like too much stuff is on automatic mode where in the console releases they left a lot up to the player's skill.  This game is taking the modern trend of putting you in like a cinematic press X repeatedly to advance the cutscene crap instead of letting the player make their own cutscene by shredding up the enemy with clever combat.  Also, this game pretty much forces you to use a controller, the keyboard controls are really clumsy and I don't think they had keyboard and mouse users in mind when they tested it.  Still fun to play, since I like blowing stuff up in the sky, but not really the Ace Combat game I was hoping for.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												Initially when this came out, I felt the controversy surrounding it was justification enough to hold off until the price dropped and then decide for myself if this game was a good direction to take the series.I gave it a chance, but the moment that an enemy locked onto me with DFM and subsequently near teleported behind me to blow me out of the sky... I just said screw it. I have no qualms with hard games and have played the previous titles all on Ace difficulty to my immense enjoyment. But the mechanics of this game are just over the top asinine. Some people say that DFM is option, and it's not. Whenever the game wants to put a tutorial in your way to show off the new system you can't opt out of it, as planes will literally spam flares, pull off absurd manuevers, and if all else fails disappear and reappear to the side to dodge an attack until you let the game put you on rails and watch the pretty explosions. No indication that it's a tutorial or rails showcase until you waste ~10 misslesGames like this that put the spectacle above the gameplay are becomming far too common. I enjoyed with the prior games just how much control you had, and the times where you had to fly through seemingly impossible turrain and tunnels gave the best adrenalline rush. It was the perfect level of arcade action that still felt 'grounded' because in the end, you were always in control. Also, moving away from a fictional world to 'modern' era ballocks... I'm tired of reality and the current political bull that plagues us with varying shades of gray. So I count this against the game as well. At least I got this on sale, but as of now I think I'm done with the series. I wouldn't mind seeing an HD collection of the prior games though, 1920x1080 @144hz... that would be something I'd definately pay a good price for.

												This game will definitely appeal to certain people...but I'm not one of them. It is, overall, a pretty braindead game that you will never really put much thought into. A few trees and buildings are actually rendered in 3D over a mesh, but the rest of the world is a extremely low res flat texture laid out on the floor like a newspaper. Homeless people sleep on prettier things than this. This is not a game where you will want to fly very close to the ground...ever. If mindless, Japanese military-wannabe games is your thing then you'll enjoy it. I personally wish I could have the time I spent on this back.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												Ace Combat Assault Horizon - Enhanced Edition is the Seventh Ace Combat game in the series, released on the PS3 and Xbox 360 in 2011 and on Steam for the PC in 2013. This was my first foray into playing the Ace Combat games on the PC, so I was surprised by the keyboard controls without the need for the mouse. This Ace Combat features CRA, Close-Range Assault, in-game known as Dogfighting Mode. This is different, as once it is engaged you are zoned in on a target and must navigate in tandum with the enemy pilot to lock missles, or just blast it with guns. Visually, I like the way Ace Combat Assault Horizon looks, especially in Dogfighting mode. This game would definitely be next-level with a flight stick and controls, as opposed to a keyboard, but is still fun. I recommend playing on harder settings as the easier settings do not present much of a challenge. The game allows you to control a stealth bomber, AC-130, fighter jet and a helicopter throughout campaign play. You can also play in Multiplayer mode, either through coop missions or in a free for all deathmatch. In all it was a fun game to play, as well as exciting. I think if you like games where you have to pilot aircraft and enjoy a fast-paced gameplay, this is going to be up your alley.

OTL...Okay, my thoughts on the game.... as my first AC game, it's a good game. Well worth the AAA price.=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=STORY=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=Tired of Russian-as-bad-guys story? I've played all CoD and BF games, and no, this one isn't as cliche as the 'haters' imply. This is an original story complete w/ sudden plot twists(!) and rising tension, albeit not your AAA novel-based but still original. This game's made in Japan, and putting oneself in a japanese gamer's shoes(even try setting the voiceover in JP(original))..... you'll realize it's a diff made game. Kinda heavily influenced and a "try" on "west's hollywood action pew pew stories/effects overuse" by the JP game industry, great job.(Haven't you noticed? It's like the devs were inspired by CoD or BF, ain't that a good kind of globalization ^o^ )=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=GAMEPLAY=-=-=-=-=-=-=Check youtube. I've played all kinds of naval, fps, and flight games. From Microsoft's Simulator to Warthunder's multiple modes. This one is ARCADE.As a first time AC player, it feels unique cuz of the camera-effects, this technique capitalizes on the normal effects(e.g. explosions, missile trailes, shell tracers) REALLY well.Oh, and I said 'check youtube' because it's *kinda* standard throughout, but it doesn't get tiresome!! try watching multiple dogfights XD!!=-=-=-=-=-=STEAM PRICING=-=-=-=-=-=-=Game pricing on Steam. Back in its day, it deserves a high price since it's one-of-a-kind among the few flight games. Today its selling point is its AC signature gameplay and name.IMHO, get it on sale instead since the norm nowadays... have set game prices cheaper.But being the first time AC-player that's also a flight junky, this being the only PC-compatible version... content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												Long story short, tl’dr version? It’s a completely sub-average action game that has a few high moments but also has some really low ones evening it out. If you can get it on sale then it’s probably worth your time, but at full price I can’t recommend it. Also as I always like to mention when reviewing a game in this genre, Ace Combat is an ARCADE flight game, meaning it’s not a hyper-realistic flight-sim but instead an action game in the air which is something I see getting confused about a lot. Much longer version? Assault Horizon isn’t a horrible game, and if you enjoy the arcade flight genre you’ll likely get at least one playthrough out of it. That said it’s definitely one if not the weakest entry in the Ace Combat series and some really weird design decisions keep it from being infinitely replayable like its forbearers.  Positives include some attractive if not top-of-the-line visuals, good voice work, and a really strong score.  But that’s where the praise ends really and it can’t make up for what the game’s lacking, and some really atrocious gameplay mechanics. First-and-foremost is the big elephant in the room that every review touches on, the automated dogfighting mode (DFM). Basically once you’ve gotten within shooting distance of an enemy you hit a key and the game pulls into a close-cam attack that has the computer automatically trailing the enemy, with you focusing on achieving lock-on.I think I know what they were going for here. They wanted to create a more cinematic experience allowing you to go through all sorts of tight turns and close-ground fly-bys that just aren’t possible for most players. But in actuality what you get is a system that takes 90% of the gameplay out of your hands, and is buggy to boot. Now I can hear what you’re saying, “Don’t use it then”, which I would love to do but the game forces you to make use of it. Enemy planes are capable of pulling impossible moves (not in a thrust vectoring way, in a literally turns 180 on the spot way that I’m pretty sure is a straight out bug) that absolutely require the use of this mode as trailing enemies, and switching between them is sluggish in manual. To make matters worse things get really…obvious as the max speed of the planes you fly increases. If your plane is faster than the enemies you enter a jumpy, stilted slide-show as your plane forcibly slows down so that you don’t go flying past the enemy making the fact that the system is totally on-rails really blatant. I’m not averse to making the experience more cinematic and entertaining, but it shouldn’t sacrifice gameplay in the process. You also have a similar process for ground assaults and bombing runs but they’re a little less on-rails making them bearable. Additionally perhaps about 1/3 of the game isn’t even in a plane. Several large parts or entire missions are from the perspective of a helicopter pilot or the door gunner. Another misguided attempt at expanding the experience but as all these missions are little more than “Hold mouse to win” it falls short. In particular the gunner levels require no skill as you only have to hit in the general vicinity of an enemy to kill them.Lastly there’s the story that’s gotten a lot of flak from longtime fans, personally I can see it from both ways but I do think it’s one of the weaker ones. On one hand they ditched the somewhat fantastical Ace-world where unrealistic super-weapons and corny but enjoyable characters were the norm for a more stock story set in the “real” world. At the same time there are the makings of a traditional Aces story.  Impossibly skilled protagonist, betrayal, crazy over-the-top unlikely war that only you can solve, etc. It’s all here and on occasion when the situations right and the music kicks in you get those warm waves of nostalgia. But the gameplays too broken and the whole “set in the real world” thing makes it hard to buy. The reason AC could get away with those silly stories was because it took place in a world where technology was different than ours, and where there were about a billion countries all vying for control, regularly splintering into new countries resulting in constant battles. It wasn’t realistic per-se but it took place in its own little bubble world that made things easier to digest. When you try to tack those same rules and morals on to the world as it exists the ridiculousness of the situation starts to shine through and become harder to enjoy. It’s not without its moments but it also limits the story. Because it takes place in the real world, or some approximation of it, that means we also don’t get any super planes/vehicles/weapons or any of the other crazy stuff AC liked to throw at you. So you’re stuck somewhere between the real and the crazy but since it can’t go full bore either way it’s just left dangling in limbo.So, yeah, if you liked previous Ace Combats or just action games in general and can pick this up on the cheap then you’ll get your 6-hours-or-so of enjoyment out of it. But too many issues plague it to make it more than a passing fling you’ll quickly abandon for something else. My time with the game wasn’t totally unenjoyable but if I hadn’t picked it up on sale I’m not sure I would feel so forgiving.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												What a shame.In an attempt to revitalize a series that didn't really need it, Namco and Project Aces wound up just dumbing it down and ripping out any charm it had in the process. The game certainly looks quite nice, it is too bad you won't get to control it half the time you're playing.The game seems intent on forcing you to watch Michael Bay-esque explosion and destruction setpieces, through the use of a new "feature" called Dog Fight Mode. I'm not sure what the intent was here, but what they did was made roughly half of the enemy fighter pilots in the game nearly impossible to shoot down by giving them an infinite amount of flares that recharge instantly, an apparent invulnerability to gun fire, and twitchy flight patterns that their aircraft should not be capable of performing.All that is to force you to activate Dog Fight Mode, a glorified Quick Time Event. It takes control away from the player (pretty much always a sign of a bad game design idea) and instead lets you nudge the plane around slightly on a preset path, with the goal of firing missiles when a circle turns red and lining up the gun sight with the enemy. It feels incredibly janky and unsatisfying.Even then, the game will pull impossible stunts and prevent you from killing the enemy jet until you fly past whatever dumb falling crane or explosion they want you to see. Because god forbid we have these things trigger naturally, that might actually be satisfying for the player. No instead the developers decide you have to see THIS exact sequence of events EXACTLY like this.Rather than having a goofy flight game with solid mechanics in an absurd setting, they went with a boring real world setting and broke the mechanics so they could shoehorn in an unwanted feature that does nothing but effectively force you to view cutscenes. I was hoping that I would be able to avoid using DFM entirely, but I guess I'm not allowed to have fun.I went into this trying to have an open mind about DFM, but the fact that the game forces you to use it is unacceptable. I honestly did not expect them to do wrong one of the few things that Tom Clancy's HAWX did right, that you never have to use the gameplay gimmick. And even as far as gameplay gimmicks go, Assistance Off is more interesting, creative, and enjoyable than DFM.In conclusion, if you are an idiot who likes games where you push a button occasionally to watch complex cutscenes instead of actually performing those actions and think yet another story about Americans and Russian terrorists fighting each other is exciting, you might like this. Otherwise I cannot recommend it.Port the PS2 games to PC instead Namco, there's money in that.In any case, I'm going to see if I can mod this game to remove DFM altogether and try to salvage something out of this mess.

Dog Fight Mode(DFM) is a cool idea(at first)Cons: DFM gets old fast, especially since there are tons of situations where it is forced on the player.A lot of the DFM battles are actually scripted, and prevent a plane from being shot down until they do something (like fire a missle at a building)The helicopter missions need a lot of work, The AC-130 mission seems like a re-text of a mission in COD4. Bomber mission is ok, but doens't bring much to the table.Aircraft selection is restricted based off of the mission. Sorry its a multi-role mission, you can't fly the Su-33.No wingman or allied control. Due to the sheer number of DFM and ASM moments(think DFM but for ground targets), the game feels like its on rails. If your a fan of previous AC games, I would recommend letting this one go. I wouldn't pay more than like 10 dollars for it. DFM and the sheer amount of eye candy the game offers are really cool for about 3 missions.  I find myself playing a select set of 3 missions, and its mainly for the soundtrack. Proably the single most annoying thing is how forced the DFM and ASM modes are. Some planes will take infinite damage unitl you start DFM, in which case they will only be shot down after a particular event occurs(ie, a bomber will not be destroyed until you start DFM with it and it is also .3 miles from its target)If your new to the series, I would recommend starting on one of the 3 AC's for the PS2 or AC6 for the Xbox-360.

												Sadly, would NOT reccomend. As much as I love the Ace Combat series, this game sadly falls short. The story and graphics aren't too shabby but the actual gameplay brings the whole thing down. I've always loved Ace Combat's not too sim-y and not too arcade-y feel but this game is way too arcade-y.They've added a Dog Fighting Mode (DFM), that you are pretty much forced to use to progress, that is basically auto-aim for planes. The little side / mini-games. where you get to use a minigun or helicopter. don't help much either when it changes the pace significantly and brings you up close and personal with the low res textures most aircraft games use for the ground you rarely see unless you are crashing. They've even added a little tweak to the turning mechanic where instead of the usual turn faster while braking they've changed it to turn extremely fast when tapping the brakes so you end up doing a feathering motion of accelerating and braking constantly to turn around quickly to jump into DRM with an opponent.All in all, I think they've gone way overboard turning this game into a pure arcade jet fighter. It seems like they changed the usual Ace Combat feel to a dumbed down version for all the pvp pwnkiddies for the great multiplayer experience that this game apparently has.

												The controls are good the graphics are good, and dropping near the dirt and buildings popping up (still mostly flat) is pretty nice.  But lets get to it, the game is about fighting, and i have to say, that even early in first thing that stuck to me was that this is a turn simulator.  you just hold onto the turn until you get a target to cross you and either hit your missles, or enter dog fight mode (dfm).  This is really it.  in the tutorial, the simplest part of the game, i was told to hold the brake and pull up until the two arrows lined up, and then level off.  What happend was i wound up doing loop the loops literally for about 2 minutes.  the arrows never lined up, and eventually i tried squirming in other directions.  The arrows never lined up.  The point of the arrows lining up is apparently to 'pull off a maneuver'.  This is to lose the fighter on your tail.  If this were to happen. . . EVER. . . id probably just want to restart and hope it didnt happen rather than push another 3 to 5 minutes trying to line up these arrows.  And then you of course go back to the circle simulator.  Going in circles and circles, gotta get that lock to auto fight.  Much of the game is auto played.  I just didnt really feel like i was piloting.

												Let me state I've already played and completed this game when it initially came out on the xbox 360. I've always been an ace combat fan so I'll admit to some bias in that regard, along with a love of military aircraft in general. That said, this itiration of the Ace Combat series, while fun, full of adrenaline, and still top notch in visual quality as you'd expect, I still felt the new Dog Fighting mechanic took away from some of the imersion. In previous titles, dog fighting was as you'd imagine, difficult. Trying to follow your target while staying in range for your main gun and leading the target so you actually hit. Posted: April 13, 2014
												I'm torn, like really torn.  I have enjoyed Ace Combat for as long as I can remember.  From going to the arcade and sitting in the, awesome at the time, faux cockpit living out my fantasies of being a fighter pilot to playing Ace Combat at home with my friends on Playstation 2.  Ace Combat, to me, has been the hands down best arcade style flight game for a long time.  Yes there were some weak games in the series, but there wasn't really anything else like them (maybe Hawx, but I have to imagine there's a reason only 2 of those were made while every other Tom Clancy game gets sequal after sequal). Now for me the best games in the series are the PS2 generation, I'm talking Shattered Skies, Unsung War, and Zero (Zero being imo the best game in the series, for story, presentation, and just sheer variety of jets).  Nothing beat going against the Yellow Squadron at the end of Shattered Skies, or being able to command my wingmen in Unsung War, or going aginst the aces of Zero.  Yes, the playstyle could get repetitive, some could even compare it to Nascar in the sky with missles, with all the constant left turns and all, but the variety of missions, the awesome stage design (chasing enemies through canyons and going all out Death Star style on giant miltary bases and destryoing giant fleets of ships just to name a few), and the insane balls to the wall story telling (Demons of Razgriz, do I have to say anything else?).  Ace Combat was  game that seemed to know what it was, first and foremost an overtly arcade flight sim (and I use the word sim very lossely).  That doesn't seem to be the case here.  Let me explain.As I stated Ace Combat has always featured crazy fictional storylines about nation against nation all out air combat.  That's not the case here.  Once again we are "graced" with the classic tale of crazy Russians doing crazy things.  Now I don't want to spoil anything, but I will say that the story, like so many others, is about revenge.  I know, real original right?  Now there have been a lot of comparisons to Call of Duty, and as someone who has played both Ace Combat and Call of Duty, I can say the comparison is apt.  There is a lot to the story that invokes thoughts of the current Call of Duty campaigns.  Once again, crazy Russians, doing crazy things, based around revengs.  I don't know if all of these game developers are delving into the same writing pool, but it sure seems that way.  The story overall, for all of it's cliches, isn't what I would call bad, but it's not what I would call good either.  Rather I would call it forgetable.  I want to say that it is a good lead in, as motivation, to the missions you play, but honestly, you could probably drop all of the cut scenes and still get the jist of what's going on.  Not that it would matter to much.  Needless to say, don't come to this game for the story, you can find the same thing, but better, in just about any movie about flying from the 80's (Top Gun, Iron Eagles), and that's not saying much.Gameplay wise is where things start to get divisive though.  Before Ace Combat was about skill, to a degree, having to keep up with your target, know when to fire missles so they would have a better chance of hitting, being able to stay in close for guns range, etc. but now that seems to have been circumvented in place of scripted action that's what many would describe as being "on rails".  Assault Horizon introduces Dog Fight Mode, or DFM for short.  Ini DFM you can engage enemies in scripted (though not to be fair, not all the tim) "on ralis" segments usually not being allowed to shoot down an enemy till you have gone through some cinematic moment the game wants you to see.  Sometimes this is a plane crashing into a stadim, as seen in the demo, othertimes it's till a plance decides to counter you, engaging you in a back and forth DFM challenge.  This can become quiet tedious, especially as the game progresses and it forces you to use such more and more.  For those that want to avoid this, I hate to inform, I don't think you really can.  There are portions of the game where it is not even possible to shoot the enemy down till you engage them in DFM and then follow through the cinematic at which time the game will actually make your weapons begin to do damage.  This, as I'm sure you can guess, get's rather old.  Thankfully though much of the previous combat does remain.  As I stated you can still engage enemies without the use of DFM and these engaements feel the same as before, if not even better, as the enemy seems to be a little bit smarter this time around, and that's not a bad thing in this case.  What is a bad thing though, is the friendly AI.  They are useless.  I don't say this lightly, but I don't think I have ever seen such horrible AI before.  I mean that.  All I'll say is this, there is a level in the game, about mid way through were you are tasked with destroying a target, you have at this time multiple aircraft in the air with you, friendly and hostile.  The friendlies task you with targetting particular aircraft informing you that they will take care of the "escort craft", they don't.  Not at all.  Nothing is more frusrtrating then seeing the sky filled with friendly aircraft only to watch them fly around not going after a single target as they tell me not to be concerned.  These targets are all over you at this point, not being concerned isn't really possible.  Especially considering it's impossible to destroy your targets without engaging the other aircraft.  oh, and did I mention you were on a timer?  Yeah, there's that.  Like I said, horrible AI.  I won't even get into the helicopter sections, this review is already long enough.  I will just say this, they aren't as bad as you may have heard, but they definettly aren't good either.  They are once again forgettable; like most of this game to be honest.I don't want to end this by doing nothing but bashing the game so I will say this, the game looks good.  It does.  It's hands down the best looking Ace Combat game.  The ground textures are still laughable, but what do you expect?  The aricraft though, beuatiful.  Also, the aircraft selection, it's good.  Granted there has been better in previous games, but what can you really expect?  It's not like there is a whole lot of modern jet fighter today.  Some of the missions were alright, but nothing to really write home about, but nothing to seriously decry either, they were just, well, forgetable.  And I guess that about sums it up, a forgetable game.  Like I said I'm torn, I really wanted to like this, it's Ace Combat, but sadly it's not.  It has the name, but none of the feel.  I'm pretty sure that JSAF may honestly be better, and that's saying something.

Posted: April 11, 2014
												AC:AH handles like the usual Ace Combat formula with the bombast and overzealous scripting of the latest Call of Duty games thrown in. Numerous times the game uses it's on-rails Dogfight Mode (DFM) or it's even more restrictive cousin Airstrike Mode to force the player to fly under -that- collapsing smokestack or -that- inexplicable jumbo jet, completely irrespective of the direction or location in which it was initiated. Allies/enemies vanish and materialise as the mission scripting decrees, or are completely invulnrable until they become a later mission objective. The DFM is also lacking in options for the player; you can just hold MG and accelerate and watch the pretty colours.The (apparently) mandatory AC-130 level, the door gunner sections and the helicopter gunship bits, I'm afraid I can't speak fairly on them. Generally I slogged through them until I got my jet back, and certainly wasn't taking notes, other than to say the ground /building textures weren't designed for hovering that close to them.The story is, well, the typical "US saves the world from someone who wants specifically to attack the US" fare we've seen everywhere since CoD 4. The comms chatter and recurring callsigns that has always made allies seem interesting is still there, but sparser and sandwiched in between asking for help and spontaneous bravado. The sense of edging along with a ground war is missing from the AC formula too - your team can hop between continent as if on an extended holiday, and the sense of bring under threat suffers. I didn't feel much attachment to the callsign either; Warwolf's leader is no Mobius One. As good as the real-world setting is, I feel Strangereal is a better setting for these games.I'm giving it a negative rating, but that's not to say a bad game. The combat is wonderfully involving in its freeform state, with an excellently majestic soundtrack (Kieki Kobayashi et al doing what they do best), a great selection of planes and enough variation in weapon loadouts / handling / mission objectives to keep it fresh. There's some character to all four members of your flight, as well as the allied squadrons and land-dwelling elements, and even the traditional objective-dispensing AWACS operator has some colour to him.In summary, what's good is most of the parts I liked from AC's 4 and 6 (you can even get the Estovakian fictional superplane from AC6, in original Strigon Squadron colours), and the parts i disliked were clearly taken wholesale from CoD and grafted around the Ace Combat experience. People looking to get the thrill arcade digfighters give would do well to look at JASF (interesting story idea there) or look to play Fires of Liberation.

I can't compare this game to previous ACE COMBAT games since this is the only ACE game on PC although, I did read that apparently, previous iterations were better according to ACE COMBAT fans. The game offers a good variety of missions in the single player campaign. Aerial combat (jet mostly) gameplay is simple enough but do take some learning curve to only focus on the Keyboard to fly the jet. Shooting down enemies while in Dog Fight Mode rocks! 												On its own, this game could be "passable." But as an Ace Combat game, it's nothing but disappointing.Yes, it fits well under the guise of "Call of Duty in planes" and that's what's wrong with it. Combat and missions are repetitive, the story is as cut-and-paste as it gets (OMG the Russians have a superweapon... again. 'Murica to the rescue!) and pretty much everything that made the old Ace Combat games great have been removed (New Game Plus, wingmate commands, plane EXP to unlock jets, etc.). Ace Combat used to take place in a distinct world that resembled our own but had unique lore. This time around they chose real-world locations so instead the story world is filled with boring real-world characters and a boring real-world story - Just like Call of Duty!Dogfight mode is a new on-rails addition that makes you semi-cinematically chase after and shoot down more skilled pilots that, simply because the game doesn't want you to, can't be shot down by conventional methods. A successful hit rips apart the enemy jet and leaves your plane splattered with oil and shrapnel and looks cool... the first few times you do it. After about mission 4 when you realize you have to do this A LOT in EVERY MISSION it gets old real fast - just like Call of Duty!Thankfully, the campaign's missions in planes are intermittently broken up by missions where you either pilot a helicopter, man the turret on a helicopter, or man the guns of a gunship. Oh, and there's one where you fly a bomber. Problem is, the control schemes were not optimized very well at all compared to when flying a fighter jet. The bombers handle like beluga swimming through jelly, and to add insult to injury they make you basically do an obstacle course in that aircraft for the one mission you get to fly it. Meanwhile the helicopters can maneuver decently but for whatever reason can't rotate left or right while precision aiming at targets, so you're left with no choice but to fire randomly while strafing. Also for some reason they think helicopters can barrel-rol without their propeller blades ripping into each other. And, of course, turret sections are, well, turret sections that add nothing to the story and are effetively action-packed story padding - just like Call of Duty!Oh, and there's a mulitplayer feature. But with how late this game's PC port was to the party, and the fact that it used to use GFWL, there's basically no one online.TL;DR: Bottom line, the trailer shows you pretty much everything the game has to offer. If that's what you like, then by all measn enjoy. But if you're a fan of previous Ace Combat titles like me, steer clear and wait for either a PC port of Ace Combat Infinity or for Namco-Bandai to finish milking Dark Souls so they can come back to this franchise. GET IT ON SALE, DO NOT BUY FULL PRICE.Pros:+ Gorgeous visuals+ Unleashing destruction in Dogfight and Airstrike Mode+ Aircraft variety (and you can mix and match secondary weapons)+ Soundtrack kicks some serious♥♥♥♥♥...Cons:- ...but the horrible song in the credits almost ruins it all- Generic 'Merica-versus-Russians story- Main antagonist's motivation is a generic revenge tale- Dogfight mode gets old fast- Planes magically unlock automatically in the story and you have little reason to try anything other than the F-22- Story missions generally give really vague objectives meaning even if you do what it says, more than likely it'll kill you anyway or randomly fail an objective and send you back to a checkpoint- Final boss is complete and total bullsh*t - He can lock 6 missiles on you at once WHILE YOU'RE BEHIND HIM- Has decent multiplayer features that aren't any use since no one plays this

Posted: May 16, 2013
												A departure from the rest of the series, but actually not too bad if you don't compare it to its predecessors. That just about sums up the entire experience as a whole. The single-player campaign takes place in the real world this time and is the first of the series to remove the player from the "silent protagonist" position. This is probably the single worst aspect of the game's setting, though there's much more to complain about as the story goes on (and ends). Unfortunately for Ace Combat fans, this isn't an enjoyable story.The gameplay is hit or miss. At first, the new DFM mode that latches you onto enemy aircraft is extremely annoying because enemies marked as TGT_LEAD are usually invulnerable until they take you for a ride between some buildings or otherwise show you a spectacle. The mode itself isn't terrible, and it isn't an auto-win; It's easy enough for enemies to break away, and the game of cat and mouse can be pretty exciting. Fans of gun kills will be disappointed, though; The traditional (useful) gunsight is gone, replaced with a static crosshair that doesn't lead targets, and the gun itself is pretty weak and unreliable to aim in DFM mode.The graphics are beautiful, if more than a little overdone on the HDR front, and the game is not limited to 1920x1200 like the trailer says; You can crank it up to any resolution you want, including Surround View / EyeFinity resolutions. There isn't much in the way of graphics settings beyond resolution, vsync and anti-aliasing, however, and there are no specific PC-only graphics features other than those. Even so, disintegrating enemy aircraft with the "steel carnage" system is impressive to watch at higher resolutions.The music and sound design are overall pretty amazing as usual. There are a few tracks that don't really impress me, but overall it sets the tone pretty well. There's a fair departure here from previous games in the series as well, though, with the music generally taking on a grittier tone, though the orchestral tracks are still there. The creaking and snapping of metal as part of the "steel carnage" system is a great touch as well.The multiplayer is where this game both shines and falls flat. When the connection is good, between good players, the game is a blast to play. While it has only four game modes, they're extremely well done. However, the netcode is very poor, and DFM mode suffers for it. It's entirely possible to be chasing someone in DFM mode only to stop in mid-air for a second and find yourself slamming into buildings and the turf because the game decided that in order for you to get to your enemy's new position, it had to rubber band you in a straight line towards them. Another problem with it is what I call skipping; If an enemy starts DFM with you, particularly if you're in an attacker, you merely need to point your nose at the ground and pull up at the last instant. No matter how far back they hang or how careful they are, they'll either have to disengage or eat the dirt. It's entirely possible to completely kill other players this way.Issues with lag aside, the game is rife with cheaters using trainers to fire infinite flares or missiles with no downtime. A good player can overcome this, but it seriously degrades the game's fun factor. As a result, there aren't that many people actually playing the game online anymore, which is sad because it actually is a lot of fun when it works.Still, while this isn't the Ace Combat game everyone wanted, it's not a terrible game overall. It has its problems, and a lot of the new things they tried with it didn't work out, but that doesn't stop it from being a lot of fun. Now, if only Namdai would release an Ace Combat HD collection with online multiplayer...

Posted: July 23, 2015
												I see a great deal of "Not Recommended" in the reviews, and it seems a great many of them tout faulty controls as a game breaker. I will tell you right now, the default controls are designed to appeal to the kind of person who has never played a flight simulator. If you go through the control menus, you will find an option to revert to a more traditional flight simulator. Something to take the majority of the game "off the rails" as it were. There will still be the occasional track shooting section, as the gunner of an AC-130, or a Blackhawk, but the meat of the game, the flying, will feel considerably more natural. This was a mistake on the developers part, to default to a more infantile method of control scheme, while bearing the relatively trusted name of ACE COMBAT, but to err is human.That being said, if you are looking for a tight, hardcore, physically sound, flight simulator, you will likely be disappointed. However, if you are a video game enthusiast, and are looking for a fun experience, this game is certainly worth a try. The game opens powerfully, focusing primarily on a hyperbolic view of dogfighting, but quickly spreads out to encompass other methods of flight to simulate. Before you know it, you'll find yourself in the seat of an AH-64 Longbow, as new mechanics are introduced. Then, you will make use of the aforementioned AC-130. Make no mistake, this is an attempt to broaden the horizons of the series, and draw in a more "action-phile" crowd. As I've seen, video game elitists hate things like this. I hope this explains the majority of the negative reviews, but if you're on Steam, you've seen the state of the internet, and you know that some people like to gripe, as they lack other methods of communicating.The tl;dr of it, I found this to be a fun game, full of amusing content, and wrought with controller breaking challenge. Admittedly, the story is bland, but I defy you to find a war game that has a truly scintillating and hereto for untold story. Take a chance, make sure to change the control scheme, and test your mettle. I wasn't disappointed, and I don't think you will be either.

												Ace Combat Assualt Horizon Enhanced Edition. What can I say about this game that most haven't already said about it already? Well for one this is one of the only games I actually bought off steam on release because I was a fan of the ace combat from the Playstation era and I saw a bunch of previews as well a friend on steam had it. I wasn't dissappointed with the game. It met most of my expectations.+ Gameplay - great gameplay. It simulates a good dog fight what you would expect (at least what I imagine an actually air combat dog fight would look like)+ Variety of planes - This game has a whole selection of planes, and even helicopters. As well as a range of weapons from Air-Air missles and Air-Ground missles+ Story isn't too complexe but it gives the game some plot that makes it interesting enough to want to see it through to the end. +Graphics - The graphics are top notch for a game of this genre. The cockpit view is astonishing though I wished they'd make taking off and landing a bit more complex to give it an actuall sim feel. Though I didn't like the obstruction in some of the cockpits of some of the fighter jets as it made that view unplayable but I also liked how u could swivel your head and look around in that view. Now some of the negatives. Albeit I thought and read at the time that normal difficulty wasn't the way to play this game as it made things a bit too easy. So I went full out and had it on elite. The first half of the game was exillerating as it made things intense and in Elite your jet didn't recover from damages as opposed to the other difficulty modes. So if you're looking for a good challange then I suggest you go this mode and its ment for veterns of the series. This is a plus and some what a negative. The DFM or (Dog Fight Mode) its the selling point to this game but I think its more of a gimmick. Well on the higher diffuculty its a must to get into this combat mode as it makes taking down enemies a neccessity as without DFM you'd have to expend a ton crap of missles to take down one or two enemies. But overall DFM mode on easier difficulties made the game too easy, and to continue on my first playthrough on Elite it became so frustrating during the Spooky mission where you were in a B2 bomber doing bombing run and helping out ground units. I kept dying and it♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off that I stopped playing this game but eventually I came back and preservered and then I came onto another hurdle in Elite that frustrated me so much that I had to bumb it down to Ace mode, it was also another non fighter jet mission which seems to be a trend. I get that they wanted to expand on the story and give the series a change of pace but the combat in the chopter and the B2- and stealth bomber missions just made the game feel off and it broke up the pacing of the game. That's also a Plus for this game as you can set the difficulty at any mission. But that also leads me to one of the biggest negatives of the game:- Different missions that require non-fighter jets.These missions over stay their welcome imo. You're introduced early on to a black hawk chopper which at first wasn't bad but the missions length go on and on. When you think its done they throw one or two final objectives and thats through out the game its just in non fighter jet missions these become tidiuous chores rather than fun objectives. Overall this is a fun game and it made me feel like I was actually pilioting and dog fighting. The fights were intense and the wide range of vehicles makes it enjoyable. I give this a 8.5/10 its worth a buy and I haven't really bought any game off release besides a couple but this is one of the games I would happily purchase full price again.

Posted: April 11, 2014
												AC:AH handles like the usual Ace Combat formula with the bombast and overzealous scripting of the latest Call of Duty games thrown in. Numerous times the game uses it's on-rails Dogfight Mode (DFM) or it's even more restrictive cousin Airstrike Mode to force the player to fly under -that- collapsing smokestack or -that- inexplicable jumbo jet, completely irrespective of the direction or location in which it was initiated. Allies/enemies vanish and materialise as the mission scripting decrees, or are completely invulnrable until they become a later mission objective. The DFM is also lacking in options for the player; you can just hold MG and accelerate and watch the pretty colours.The (apparently) mandatory AC-130 level, the door gunner sections and the helicopter gunship bits, I'm afraid I can't speak fairly on them. Generally I slogged through them until I got my jet back, and certainly wasn't taking notes, other than to say the ground /building textures weren't designed for hovering that close to them.The story is, well, the typical "US saves the world from someone who wants specifically to attack the US" fare we've seen everywhere since CoD 4. The comms chatter and recurring callsigns that has always made allies seem interesting is still there, but sparser and sandwiched in between asking for help and spontaneous bravado. The sense of edging along with a ground war is missing from the AC formula too - your team can hop between continent as if on an extended holiday, and the sense of bring under threat suffers. I didn't feel much attachment to the callsign either; Warwolf's leader is no Mobius One. As good as the real-world setting is, I feel Strangereal is a better setting for these games.I'm giving it a negative rating, but that's not to say a bad game. The combat is wonderfully involving in its freeform state, with an excellently majestic soundtrack (Kieki Kobayashi et al doing what they do best), a great selection of planes and enough variation in weapon loadouts / handling / mission objectives to keep it fresh. There's some character to all four members of your flight, as well as the allied squadrons and land-dwelling elements, and even the traditional objective-dispensing AWACS operator has some colour to him.In summary, what's good is most of the parts I liked from AC's 4 and 6 (you can even get the Estovakian fictional superplane from AC6, in original Strigon Squadron colours), and the parts i disliked were clearly taken wholesale from CoD and grafted around the Ace Combat experience. People looking to get the thrill arcade digfighters give would do well to look at JASF (interesting story idea there) or look to play Fires of Liberation.

												Well, I bought this game on a special promotion and since I am an Ace Combat veteran, I had to get it. I was a little nervous about buying an Ace Combat game for the PC and it appears that I was rightly so. This one is not your typical Ace Combat game. There is a new dogfighting mode, helicopter piloting and door gunning. My first challenge was to get control of the game. The jet fighter was easy enough (grab my PS2 controller with pc adapter, plug in and configure), but for the helicopter and gunner sequences, that controller didn't cut it. I had to configure my Belkin n52te controller in concert with my mouse to accurately control the helicopter and the mouse was really key to being effective with the gunner sequences. Once I got a handle on the controls, the fun began. Flying the jet for me was pretty much a blast from the past. Machine guns, missiles, special weapons, etc... all there. DFM (Dog Fighting Mode), however, was a new one on me. In the past, there were enemies that were better than the other ones and if you killed them, you got medals and such. Well, on this game there are lead targets and the only way you can take them out is by following them until you can activate the DFM and shoot them down. There have been mixed reactions to the DFM, I personally have no problem with it and it does come in handy in many situations. Also, you can BE engaged by an enemy in DFM. In this instance, there is a little button that can be pushed at the right time that will perform a dizzing evasive manuver that will put you behind the plane and you then have your chance to shoot it down. Pretty sweet to me, I like it. Also, the other new feature is flares. Someone fires a missle at you, deploy flares and turn to evade. Simple enough. The jet fighter sequences are definately enjoyable. Helicopter flying is a different story. I HAD to get my n52te and mouse to fly this thing effectively. There was no way that my PS2 controller or my keyboard was going to cut it on this one. I had to be able to turn, hover to the left or right and be able to fire at the same time. That was too much of a challenge for a PS2 controller. So, once I got a handle on controlling it effectively, I had fun with it. There is your turrent gun, rockets and air-to-ground missiles. Once you learn how to control the helicopter well, it is just as enjoyable as the jet fighter sequences. And the dialogue from the helicopter pilot will crack you up on occasion. :-)Door gunning is fairly simple. You have a set of cross-hairs that you put on the enemy and shoot. Right mouse button zooms in. Shoot all enemies. Shoot, kill, kill, kill, shoot, kill, kill, kill. The mouse will assist you with more accurate shots than the keyboard or controllers will. Once you get into it, you'll love it.Overall, this is a successful game. The controls took a lot of getting used to, but once you got the hang of it and customized the controls to your playing style, you'll love it. Buy it with confidence.

Posted: May 16, 2013
												A departure from the rest of the series, but actually not too bad if you don't compare it to its predecessors. That just about sums up the entire experience as a whole. The single-player campaign takes place in the real world this time and is the first of the series to remove the player from the "silent protagonist" position. This is probably the single worst aspect of the game's setting, though there's much more to complain about as the story goes on (and ends). Unfortunately for Ace Combat fans, this isn't an enjoyable story.The gameplay is hit or miss. At first, the new DFM mode that latches you onto enemy aircraft is extremely annoying because enemies marked as TGT_LEAD are usually invulnerable until they take you for a ride between some buildings or otherwise show you a spectacle. The mode itself isn't terrible, and it isn't an auto-win; It's easy enough for enemies to break away, and the game of cat and mouse can be pretty exciting. Fans of gun kills will be disappointed, though; The traditional (useful) gunsight is gone, replaced with a static crosshair that doesn't lead targets, and the gun itself is pretty weak and unreliable to aim in DFM mode.The graphics are beautiful, if more than a little overdone on the HDR front, and the game is not limited to 1920x1200 like the trailer says; You can crank it up to any resolution you want, including Surround View / EyeFinity resolutions. There isn't much in the way of graphics settings beyond resolution, vsync and anti-aliasing, however, and there are no specific PC-only graphics features other than those. Even so, disintegrating enemy aircraft with the "steel carnage" system is impressive to watch at higher resolutions.The music and sound design are overall pretty amazing as usual. There are a few tracks that don't really impress me, but overall it sets the tone pretty well. There's a fair departure here from previous games in the series as well, though, with the music generally taking on a grittier tone, though the orchestral tracks are still there. The creaking and snapping of metal as part of the "steel carnage" system is a great touch as well.The multiplayer is where this game both shines and falls flat. When the connection is good, between good players, the game is a blast to play. While it has only four game modes, they're extremely well done. However, the netcode is very poor, and DFM mode suffers for it. It's entirely possible to be chasing someone in DFM mode only to stop in mid-air for a second and find yourself slamming into buildings and the turf because the game decided that in order for you to get to your enemy's new position, it had to rubber band you in a straight line towards them. Another problem with it is what I call skipping; If an enemy starts DFM with you, particularly if you're in an attacker, you merely need to point your nose at the ground and pull up at the last instant. No matter how far back they hang or how careful they are, they'll either have to disengage or eat the dirt. It's entirely possible to completely kill other players this way.Issues with lag aside, the game is rife with cheaters using trainers to fire infinite flares or missiles with no downtime. A good player can overcome this, but it seriously degrades the game's fun factor. As a result, there aren't that many people actually playing the game online anymore, which is sad because it actually is a lot of fun when it works.Still, while this isn't the Ace Combat game everyone wanted, it's not a terrible game overall. It has its problems, and a lot of the new things they tried with it didn't work out, but that doesn't stop it from being a lot of fun. Now, if only Namdai would release an Ace Combat HD collection with online multiplayer...

Posted: April 9, 2014
												Ace Combat was an OK game with a relatively boring story line.While some might perhaps appreciate the warbirds, I can't say that the selection was amazing, nor that your average coinesseur would be impressed with the selection. The music and sounds were alright, but again, nothing to write home about. As a flying game, this isn't going to be taking back any medals in that department.My main gripe is with how short this game was - playing for only a couple days, with maybe 30-45 minutes of cutscenes, the majority of that time was spent re-doing annoying parts of missions - not so much annoying due to their difficulty or finesse so much as due to dumb, brokenness of the game itself. After a couple short battles in which you learn the basics of gameplay (read, you learn how simple it is to play), you are introduced to the game's cast and go on a couple, mildly interesting runs to quash some rebels. You quickly learn who the bad-guys are, and from there, its mostly predictable "go kill this there". Hardly any character development, no interesting fights, a lot of 'more of the same' dogfights. Well, almost.There were a couple levels which were really enjoyable, like the bomber levels and the rail-shooter helicopter level - and the helicopter level at the end. Unfortunately, nearly all the action was spent spinning in circles, auto-locking the enemy in a warbird. But each one of these levels had no other level like them in the whole game - maybe development time was limited, but it didn't feel so much like a game as a prototype experiment with a couple test modes to play. And most of the air-levels were 'more of the same' ones - chase flocks of 'bandits' around, in a methodical manner, take them out one by one, while your team sits around getting maybe one kill for every five that you get. Your team, which usually consists of a single air squadron that, guess what, flies around in circles. This got so bad, the final level feels downright anti-climactic, since you end up just in another 'more of the same' fights, with less actual birds than in most of the rest of the game - or at least it seemed that way. Sure, at least you get to go one-on-one with your archnemesis, but beyond that battle being difficult, the game finishes with a weak wheezle. I kinda think the team fired their game designer, because I don't see much evidence that a game was designed at all, and its not just some bad jet-fighter simulator.So is it any good as a simulator then, perhaps? Maybe, the actual flying seems to work ok and you can pretend to fight other jets. Five stars there. But the mechanics, as mentioned are somewhat broken. First off, very annoying, you cannot turn off hints. If, for whatever reason, you need to redo part of a level, or even if you just want to replay that level, you must have your fun interupted for 5 seconds by instructions written for a five year old. Yes, yes pressing that button might be helpful. First time's good, 10th time, not so much. Not to mention, the instructions given are garbage - they are simple enough, but given the highly actionable nature of the game, it would be much better to give a visual representation of the maneuver and let the player practice than to present a paragraph of text which doesn't mean a whole lot to someone in the middle of a battle. Though, as I said, they are pretty simple anyways, and you will pick them up during play, but better to scrap the instructions as they are entirely in my opinion.There were also a couple of quirks in the game; in the second bomber run, after your initial bombing streak, when you switch to guided penetration missiles, the game will run you through one of its 'guided runs', and then confusingly position you so that you can't see any of the targets, as well as start you out going too fast. Yes, its relatively simple to fix this, but its a 'guided run', why on earth is it like this if you're going to force me into a pseudo rail-shooter mode? Its not even like you need to alternate height. Secondly, in the same level, actually, during the ICBM chase mode, if you fail to catch the missile the first time, you will be autospawned and given 3 seconds to figure out what to do. Given the instructions 'catch the missile' and the results for failing to do so 'it is out of your altidue range', it is in no way obvious that 'accelerate at breakneck speed after the missile' is the solution. Finally, again, in the same (poorly desinged) level, in the third section of the first bombing run, the solution is a bit at random, as the vehicles will change direction at random, and sometimes escape, yet they count towards a failure. Not technically a bug, and as there is a solution, its just challenging and not broken, but wondering why you keep failing that run despite carpeting everything the first three times, is a bit annoying.All in all, it could have been a better game - fix some quirks, add a bit of depth and storyline, and this could have gone from 'OK game' to 'Good Game', but its nowhere close in my books.For the price that I got this, 7 bucks, I'm out no more than the price of a bad film at the theatre, but I'd still not recommend it unless you have nothing better to do or play. And that's pretty unlikely.

Posted: July 23, 2015
												I see a great deal of "Not Recommended" in the reviews, and it seems a great many of them tout faulty controls as a game breaker. I will tell you right now, the default controls are designed to appeal to the kind of person who has never played a flight simulator. If you go through the control menus, you will find an option to revert to a more traditional flight simulator. Something to take the majority of the game "off the rails" as it were. There will still be the occasional track shooting section, as the gunner of an AC-130, or a Blackhawk, but the meat of the game, the flying, will feel considerably more natural. This was a mistake on the developers part, to default to a more infantile method of control scheme, while bearing the relatively trusted name of ACE COMBAT, but to err is human.That being said, if you are looking for a tight, hardcore, physically sound, flight simulator, you will likely be disappointed. However, if you are a video game enthusiast, and are looking for a fun experience, this game is certainly worth a try. The game opens powerfully, focusing primarily on a hyperbolic view of dogfighting, but quickly spreads out to encompass other methods of flight to simulate. Before you know it, you'll find yourself in the seat of an AH-64 Longbow, as new mechanics are introduced. Then, you will make use of the aforementioned AC-130. Make no mistake, this is an attempt to broaden the horizons of the series, and draw in a more "action-phile" crowd. As I've seen, video game elitists hate things like this. I hope this explains the majority of the negative reviews, but if you're on Steam, you've seen the state of the internet, and you know that some people like to gripe, as they lack other methods of communicating.The tl;dr of it, I found this to be a fun game, full of amusing content, and wrought with controller breaking challenge. Admittedly, the story is bland, but I defy you to find a war game that has a truly scintillating and hereto for untold story. Take a chance, make sure to change the control scheme, and test your mettle. I wasn't disappointed, and I don't think you will be either.

Well for one this is one of the only games I actually bought off steam on release because I was a fan of the ace combat from the Playstation era and I saw a bunch of previews as well a friend on steam had it. I wasn't dissappointed with the game. It met most of my expectations.+ Gameplay - great gameplay. It simulates a good dog fight what you would expect (at least what I imagine an actually air combat dog fight would look like)+ Variety of planes - This game has a whole selection of planes, and even helicopters. As well as a range of weapons from Air-Air missles and Air-Ground missles+ Story isn't too complexe but it gives the game some plot that makes it interesting enough to want to see it through to the end. +Graphics - The graphics are top notch for a game of this genre. The cockpit view is astonishing though I wished they'd make taking off and landing a bit more complex to give it an actuall sim feel. Though I didn't like the obstruction in some of the cockpits of some of the fighter jets as it made that view unplayable but I also liked how u could swivel your head and look around in that view. Now some of the negatives. Albeit I thought and read at the time that normal difficulty wasn't the way to play this game as it made things a bit too easy. So I went full out and had it on elite. The first half of the game was exillerating as it made things intense and in Elite your jet didn't recover from damages as opposed to the other difficulty modes. So if you're looking for a good challange then I suggest you go this mode and its ment for veterns of the series. This is a plus and some what a negative. The DFM or (Dog Fight Mode) its the selling point to this game but I think its more of a gimmick. Well on the higher diffuculty its a must to get into this combat mode as it makes taking down enemies a neccessity as without DFM you'd have to expend a ton crap of missles to take down one or two enemies. But overall DFM mode on easier difficulties made the game too easy, and to continue on my first playthrough on Elite it became so frustrating during the Spooky mission where you were in a B2 bomber doing bombing run and helping out ground units. I kept dying and it♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off that I stopped playing this game but eventually I came back and preservered and then I came onto another hurdle in Elite that frustrated me so much that I had to bumb it down to Ace mode, it was also another non fighter jet mission which seems to be a trend. I get that they wanted to expand on the story and give the series a change of pace but the combat in the chopter and the B2- and stealth bomber missions just made the game feel off and it broke up the pacing of the game. That's also a Plus for this game as you can set the difficulty at any mission. But that also leads me to one of the biggest negatives of the game:- Different missions that require non-fighter jets.These missions over stay their welcome imo. You're introduced early on to a black hawk chopper which at first wasn't bad but the missions length go on and on. When you think its done they throw one or two final objectives and thats through out the game its just in non fighter jet missions these become tidiuous chores rather than fun objectives. Overall this is a fun game and it made me feel like I was actually pilioting and dog fighting. The fights were intense and the wide range of vehicles makes it enjoyable. I give this a 8.5/10 its worth a buy and I haven't really bought any game off release besides a couple but this is one of the games I would happily purchase full price again.

												The black sheep of the Ace Combat franchise. I was EXTREMELY hyped for this title prior to release. Ace Combat 5 is my favourite game of all time, and I thought this would kick the franchise back into gear again. How foolish.Cons:- The gameplay is nothing like the earlier games, so die hard fans will find almost nothing of value here. - The infamous and bizarre dog-fighting sections play like some on-rails arcade shooter. - There are enforced helicopter sections (admittedly a little fun sometimes), enforced third-person gunner sections (again, sometimes fun) and awful bombing missions with overly-complicated recommended flight paths. - The colour scheme is mostly grey/dark green. - The over all combat is ultimately tedious due to over powered nature of your plane. -  The story is forgettable at best. Nothing compared to the grand and bombastic entries into the Strangereal lore in earlier games.But, for all of that. there is some light to this.Pros:- The port is solid (I'm only judging this after 30 minutes of playing, but nothing has crashed and there are minimal frame drops. Graphics settings are sparse though.)- There are a few jaw-dropping moments, usually involving something to do with ejecting from the craft.- The later missions get extremely intense. The penultimate one is actually fantastic.- The gameplay is solid if you enjoy what it offers. Planes are responsive and destroying enemies is satisfying.- Nagase from AC5 makes an easter egg appearance.- The main theme is Ace Combat-esque, and thrilling for it. Also has a couple of other good tracks, like the free mission hangar OST, which serves as a nice throwback to the PS1 days of the seriesMost of my negativity is just from being so heartbroken that this essentially damned the franchise. I don't want to be an♥♥♥♥♥♥and not recommend it for that reason. If this is your first time playing Ace Combat, give it a whirl.Then get a PS2 and play the better ones

Posted: June 26, 2015
												NOTICE - THIS REVIEW WAS WRITTEN USING GAME RESEARCH AND ALSO ME EXPERIENCE AFTER 3 HOURS OF PLAY.No, this is not worth buying, whether it be full price or on sale. Ace Combat is a series that has yet to join PC and is a series that may not ever join the PC even though flight games are right at home here. Firstly, the game's port is bare bones. The game did not work for me at first and I had to keep restarting Steam and validating the system files etc. Alongside that, there are very few options, the game doesn't look that great even on the highest settings, and the game can crash if you alt-tab. However, in it's defence, the game does run well on my GTX 960, but that is by no means a low end card.The game is breaks down in to two chunks, on rail turret sections and dogfight sections, both of which are very dull and last way too long. The on-rail shooting sections are about as fun as they sound - click the mouse to make an explosion, do it again until the section ends...which takes a long time. The sections can last about 20 minutes at times, and if it is shorter, it certainly feels like they go on forever. The dogfight sections are pretty much - get behind the target, lock on, shoot them with missiles, maybe lock on further to get more accuracy and watch them explode. It is boring, goes on forever, and feels unrealistic. You also get a minigun which is useless and does no noticeable damage to the enemies, and you can't tell if you are hitting them because there are no hitmarkers.As for the story, I didn't get what was going on and I didn't even know who I was fighting because the game bored me so much I didn't care to get far in the game. There is also mouse acceleration in the on-rail shooting sections and no mouse control at all in the flight sections, so if you REALLY care to play this game, a controller is reccomended. The world also looks like they ripped a world from Google maps, as the skyscrapers, ground and even the explosions look very low resolution. The planes do look decent however. The game is boring, the PC port is mediocre at best, and levels last way too long, and judging from other reviews, this is not what Ace Combat is really like and I am taking their word for it as I haven't played any other games in the series. Do not buy this game even if it is on sale. +Planes look decent+Performance is acceptable-Boring combat-Over-long levels-Barebones PC port-Boring visuals-Multiplayer is dead-Story is boring-Only 8 hours long with no replay-OVERALL BORINGEDIT - I have been informed that there are also Helicopter sections, however these are similar to the flying sections without the speed. Also apparently the game is supposed to give you an adrenaline rush? Does it f*ck. I stand by what I have said in this review.

Posted: February 13, 2015
												If you want a realistic flight simulator, skip this game and go look somewhere else. This game is about pure action and does not bother with realism the slightest.If you don't mind carrying 200 missiles in your fighter jet, shooting down fleets of enemy aircraft, and dodging missiles by making barrel rolls with your helicopter, as long as the adreline rush is there - then this is the game for you.Ace Combat: AH will not impress you with its story and its many seen-from-miles-away plot twists. It will however keep you in the heart of the action from the beginning till the end; it is very good at keeping the tension up all the time, making you feel like you're in a constant rush - and you will be. You're the guy defusing the bomb with its timer nearing zero, except you're doing so in an aircraft, and there's a new bomb every 5 minutes.While the difficulty curve is erratic at best (some missions are very easy, while some can get frustrating - especially the last one which sees a huge spike in difficulty and can result in many a scream at the screen), the adreline rush is there all the time - whether you're engaged in a dogfight with another fighter jet and trying to match its movements as it zig zags between buildings in the heart of a city, whether you're saturing the sky with missiles to keep enemy jets out of the hair of the transport you're defending, whether you're dropping dozens of bombs on an enemy base to blow it up while dodging incoming SAMs, whether you're sending salves after salves of rockets from your Apache helicopter at incoming columns of armour to prevent them from reaching your too-vulnerable infantry, or whether you're trying to out- or counter-manoeuver an enemy jet who's tailing you, your breath will be held from the beginning till the end of the fight. That's the real strength of this game.So if you want an fast-paced, action-packed aerial shooter with a much appreciable soundtrack which complements its intensity in a very fitting way, go ahead and give this game a try. It's not the longest one of the bunch nor the most mind-blowing, but it'll keep you entertained for its 10~ hours worth of material, and will offer you more if you want to keep at it.
