												Your reaction to this game, be it positive or negative, will likely mirror your reaction to the following sentence:This is not Ace Combat.If you just want a quick review, that's probably all you need to know. If, for whatever reason, you would like me to ramble aimlessly elaborate, I will do so.   First, it is necessary for me to admit here and now that as a longtime fan of the Ace Combat series, I personally, am unable to give a truly unbiased review of this game. As such, my issue with this entry in the series is primarily the drastic departure from the core gameplay of said series. There are a multitude of these "departures", many of which you've likely already heard complaints about, and thus I won't go into. Now if upon reading this your assumption is "This person is just bitter that they changed the gameplay around", I wouldn't hold it against you, as you'd be right.   To be fair, there is a lot of good in this game. The presentation is great. Everything looks good, and this game has probably the best visual detail we've seen in this series so far. The sound is excellent as well, ranging from punchy and immersive (if not always realistic) sound effects, to the little things, like the multilingual onboard computers of the various planes, not to mention a fantastic soundtrack.   One may ask, "Who then, is this game geared towards?" Well, to put it bluntly, this is a game for casuals. I'll spare you the old jaded gamer diatribe, and say this; If you simply want a flashy casual action game, then this game was deliberatly developed and marketed towards such a demographic. It even says so on the cases of physical copies of the game; "Call of Duty in the air", and that's exactly what it is. That, in and of itself, is not bad. That said, this game, being what it is means I must repeat this sentiment:This is not Ace Combat.   Why then, are these contentious issues? Well, quite frankly, Ace Combat is a niche series. This game could quite easily have been presented as a spinoff with a different title, which may or may not have alleviated some of the negative reaction, who knows. Thing is, this game carries the Ace Combat name for brand value. A brand that, in all honesty is not as popular or widespread as my fellow fans and I, and perhaps Namco-Bandai as well, would like to believe.   Having said all of that, it seems as though the developers have realized this, as the game that followed this title; Ace Combat Infinity (PS3 exclusive as of this writing) has gone back to the "old" style, though not without its own share of issues, which I won't waste even more of your time with. So perhaps this game was, in a way, a necessary step. By that, I mean, in regards to seeing what would work and what wouldn't. In the end, did it work? Well, that depends on your personal viewpoint on this statement, which i'll repeat for the last time:This is not Ace Combat.   When all is said and done, this is not a game for us, the Ace Combat fanbase. But what about you? Maybe you don't consider yourself a "hardcore" fan. There's nothing wrong with that. And if that is indeed the case, you might just enjoy this game.

This game basically wants you to enjoy the explosions happening around you and make you feel like some badass pilot, but in reality you're occasionally tilting your stick, holding down one button, and when you hear the right sound you want, press the other button.Let's get down to the meat. He doesn't know who the ♥♥♥♥ he is and you'll lose track of his internal conflict after the first mission because he barely talks about it again until the end of the game. Some Russian group is up to no good and you got to beat them up. So pick your plane out of the preset "please use these planes because they don't break the mission" list, then you're off. Oh wait, that's not every mission. Some missions require you to be in a helicopter that can take collisions into buildings and other missions make you be the machine gunner on the helicopter. That's cool but it's not Ace Combat.Ace Combat is about jerking off to people calling you the legendary beast or having some Spanish guitar in the background strumming a catchy chorus while you ejaculate over the screen to some female saying that she doesn't want to fight a war. In this game, you're Beef McTruckHam fighting for the greater American good with some heavy thrashing music in the background every other level.Levels get frustrating as you may get annoyed by the DFM system and end up not holding a button long enough to shoot something to death. Other times you get distracted by optional enemies during a sudden timelimit. This game gets frustrating and you'll probably only replay 3 or 4 missions.So should you buy this?Yeah, but don't treat it like an Ace Combat game. Treat it like you're playing Call of Duty in the skies, because that is what it'll ever be.

												Ace Combat Assualt Horizon Enhanced Edition. What can I say about this game that most haven't already said about it already? Well for one this is one of the only games I actually bought off steam on release because I was a fan of the ace combat from the Playstation era and I saw a bunch of previews as well a friend on steam had it. I wasn't dissappointed with the game. It met most of my expectations.+ Gameplay - great gameplay. It simulates a good dog fight what you would expect (at least what I imagine an actually air combat dog fight would look like)+ Variety of planes - This game has a whole selection of planes, and even helicopters. As well as a range of weapons from Air-Air missles and Air-Ground missles+ Story isn't too complexe but it gives the game some plot that makes it interesting enough to want to see it through to the end. +Graphics - The graphics are top notch for a game of this genre. The cockpit view is astonishing though I wished they'd make taking off and landing a bit more complex to give it an actuall sim feel. Though I didn't like the obstruction in some of the cockpits of some of the fighter jets as it made that view unplayable but I also liked how u could swivel your head and look around in that view. Now some of the negatives. Albeit I thought and read at the time that normal difficulty wasn't the way to play this game as it made things a bit too easy. So I went full out and had it on elite. The first half of the game was exillerating as it made things intense and in Elite your jet didn't recover from damages as opposed to the other difficulty modes. So if you're looking for a good challange then I suggest you go this mode and its ment for veterns of the series. This is a plus and some what a negative. The DFM or (Dog Fight Mode) its the selling point to this game but I think its more of a gimmick. Well on the higher diffuculty its a must to get into this combat mode as it makes taking down enemies a neccessity as without DFM you'd have to expend a ton crap of missles to take down one or two enemies. But overall DFM mode on easier difficulties made the game too easy, and to continue on my first playthrough on Elite it became so frustrating during the Spooky mission where you were in a B2 bomber doing bombing run and helping out ground units. I kept dying and it♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off that I stopped playing this game but eventually I came back and preservered and then I came onto another hurdle in Elite that frustrated me so much that I had to bumb it down to Ace mode, it was also another non fighter jet mission which seems to be a trend. I get that they wanted to expand on the story and give the series a change of pace but the combat in the chopter and the B2- and stealth bomber missions just made the game feel off and it broke up the pacing of the game. That's also a Plus for this game as you can set the difficulty at any mission. But that also leads me to one of the biggest negatives of the game:- Different missions that require non-fighter jets.These missions over stay their welcome imo. You're introduced early on to a black hawk chopper which at first wasn't bad but the missions length go on and on. When you think its done they throw one or two final objectives and thats through out the game its just in non fighter jet missions these become tidiuous chores rather than fun objectives. Overall this is a fun game and it made me feel like I was actually pilioting and dog fighting. The fights were intense and the wide range of vehicles makes it enjoyable. I give this a 8.5/10 its worth a buy and I haven't really bought any game off release besides a couple but this is one of the games I would happily purchase full price again.

Posted: June 26, 2015
												NOTICE - THIS REVIEW WAS WRITTEN USING GAME RESEARCH AND ALSO ME EXPERIENCE AFTER 3 HOURS OF PLAY.No, this is not worth buying, whether it be full price or on sale. Ace Combat is a series that has yet to join PC and is a series that may not ever join the PC even though flight games are right at home here. Firstly, the game's port is bare bones. The game did not work for me at first and I had to keep restarting Steam and validating the system files etc. Alongside that, there are very few options, the game doesn't look that great even on the highest settings, and the game can crash if you alt-tab. However, in it's defence, the game does run well on my GTX 960, but that is by no means a low end card.The game is breaks down in to two chunks, on rail turret sections and dogfight sections, both of which are very dull and last way too long. The on-rail shooting sections are about as fun as they sound - click the mouse to make an explosion, do it again until the section ends...which takes a long time. The sections can last about 20 minutes at times, and if it is shorter, it certainly feels like they go on forever. The dogfight sections are pretty much - get behind the target, lock on, shoot them with missiles, maybe lock on further to get more accuracy and watch them explode. It is boring, goes on forever, and feels unrealistic. You also get a minigun which is useless and does no noticeable damage to the enemies, and you can't tell if you are hitting them because there are no hitmarkers.As for the story, I didn't get what was going on and I didn't even know who I was fighting because the game bored me so much I didn't care to get far in the game. There is also mouse acceleration in the on-rail shooting sections and no mouse control at all in the flight sections, so if you REALLY care to play this game, a controller is reccomended. The world also looks like they ripped a world from Google maps, as the skyscrapers, ground and even the explosions look very low resolution. The planes do look decent however. The game is boring, the PC port is mediocre at best, and levels last way too long, and judging from other reviews, this is not what Ace Combat is really like and I am taking their word for it as I haven't played any other games in the series. Do not buy this game even if it is on sale. +Planes look decent+Performance is acceptable-Boring combat-Over-long levels-Barebones PC port-Boring visuals-Multiplayer is dead-Story is boring-Only 8 hours long with no replay-OVERALL BORINGEDIT - I have been informed that there are also Helicopter sections, however these are similar to the flying sections without the speed. Also apparently the game is supposed to give you an adrenaline rush? Does it f*ck. I stand by what I have said in this review.

												I went into this game expecting another great installment like Shattered Skies or The Unsung War, set in the universes they were in, with a great story and similiar flight mechanics. What I got was a game that felt like it had been "CODified" so to speak. The campaign in Ace Combat games has always had an anmazing story with great characters. This just felt like call of duty but with planes instead, using re-hashed cliches and ideas of having the russians be the bad guys and installing parts like the helicopter gunner which does not belong in this game. I hated it the more I played, very little that i did. The whole system of the close-range assualt system was just complete garbage. It adds no value to the game, just more ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t they pile on to give it a "cinematic" feel. The "dramatic realistic storyline" was another insult as well. Something that has been done time and again, its just a lazy♥♥♥♥♥♥story they cobbled together to try and have some sort of setting made with no effort for the game. All the intense moments in Shattered Skies and Unsung War were amazing, like when Nagase was in danger as her plane was going down, but then she ends up rescuing fellow soldiers and taking some enemies hostage right after ejecting like a hardass; or you are protecting a rocket that needs to deliver a ♥♥♥♥ing laser to a low orbit plane to give you an edge in the war, or when you have to shoot down that same plane when the enemy takes it. All of the banter between the pilots and command was really funny, dramatic, and had actual emotion to it. Unique, colorful, and masterpieces of missions and storytelling. This entire game is a stain and shameful mark upon the legacy and awe left by those earlier games, not fit to share the title of Ace Combat. If I could I would wipe this game from my library just so I dont have to look at such a pile of excrement. Do not buy this game if you have played the previous masterpieces. If your a COD fanboy who likes campaigns that only take a few hours to complete, and the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t story cliches time and time again, this is right up your alley.

Posted: July 27, 2014
												Ignoring its title and separating it from the previous Ace Combat games does little to save it from its own faults. Ace Combat: Assault Horizon takes a step back from the interesting, if not corny world of Strangereal, and plays the Russian/American conflict card. This tired formulaic story is complemented by a downgrade in gameplay. Dogfighting is made simple, and boring, with the introduction of a near-rail-shooter experience that removes the freedom from flight and negates the need for skillful airmanship. It would be acceptable to have a “boss” flight lead require this mechanic, but every flight lead requires that you lock into dogfight mode; even if you land missiles on target, the game ignores the hits and will not progress until you put on your training wheels and go for the ride. The game does include a new diversity of aircraft with the introduction of helicopters and bombers, which if properly executed would nearly save the game, but bomber runs are not particularly fun and the helicopter sections are tedious and awkward. Overall, the game looks great graphically (although the graphical settings are sparse) and gives you a decently realistic flight simulation, but its glaring flaws make it just an okay experience. Personally, I would award 3/5 stars to this game and would recommend picking it up only if it happens to be on sale.

Posted: July 25, 2014
												This game has too many flaws in it to be enjoyable.  This game isn't worthy of the title of Ace Combat.  I want to go in with an open mind but it just has terrible game mechanics.  From planes performing impossible moves to the dog fight not engaging at the correct time, this game can aggrivate even the most hardcore veterans of the Ace Combat series.  The development crew must have been a bunch of guys who grew up with COD and wanted to emulate it to the letter, with bad story telling and just making certain that there is an explosion every 3 seconds.The story could have been a lot better, but the writers decided to go with the most severly ADD pilot I have ever met and to have no depth with character development.  They also wanted to go for the whole Russia is bad theme that COD has beaten to death and then some.  I mean I get the fact that from the Cold War, Russia has never got rid of their stigma of being evil, but I mean come on, lets see something more interesting.  The main villian of the series lacks a true motive for what he is doing, and, personally, they really needed to expand his backstory.  I got to say it was pretty boring when the AC-130 level came into play, cause I was spoiled by how good COD's version was (I will say that that was my favorite level in COD).  You would think that a game producer who focuses just on aircraft would have a better grasp on this.  I will say that the helicopter missions were definitly interesting and a breath of fresh air, once you died 20 times just trying to get used to the new controls.The gameplay mechanics are another point in the game that actually hurt it.  The dogfight mode is intersting, but annoying when you lockon a target and face an invincible fighter plane, because the producers want you to go through their house of explosions before you can take him out.  Also I have had this little problem affect me multiple times, I will be in the dogfight mode and the enemy plane nose-dives into the ground, and you would think that that is one less plane I have to worry about. Wrong, because your plane will also quickly follow suit and explode, just because dogfight wants you to have the nose of your aircraft so far up the enemies exhaust, that you could just pull the fuel lines, that you also share the fate due to bad AI pathing.  Also while the cinematic following of the missles is pretty cool, it just detracts from the game and causes you to sit in your chair for an extra 5 seconds, while you could be shooting down the other guys who is in front of you.  Once you come out of it 9 times out of 10, they have escaped.  Also the quicktime events are dumb, they offer no, I repeat no, effect on the game, but their are about 3 out of 20-something quicktime events that will make you fail a mission.The last major problem I had is that the game isn't that hard.  Changing the difficulty isn't really a test of your skill, like having less ammunition or the AI being smarter, rather it's just how much more that the AI can defy physics and perform outragious moves.  One example is the final dog fight and it has to be done in dogfight mode.  If you break dog fight with the enemy, then the enemy can perform some weird 360-180 backflip, with a double axial from hell and be right on your rear.  Sure it makes it harder but it is just something that isn't that fun to deal with.The good thing about this game is the normal dogfighting, not that stupid lockon behind them crap.  It was a blast to relive the old system of using the IFF to track down targets and just shoot them down.  That was a method that proved your worth in the old games, where if you couldn't manually track behind your targets and tack them out with missles of guns, you were dead.If you are a new flyer to the Ace Combat series and were either turned off or interested in the series, I recommend that you get a ps2 and play Ace Combat 5 and/or Ace Combat 0.  The reason is simple, the Ace Combat series is hands down one of the best jet fighter sims out there, and this version was just a disgrace.  Now maybe I'm a guy who just enjoys living in the past, but I can tell you that this game had potential but terrible execution.Keep those skies clear.(PS I don't like to put spoliers in my reviews, so I am unable to explain, in this already long review, certain key elements in the story that are just bad.  Also I don't really play multiplayer due to internet problems.  So my review is focused towards those who enjoy the campagin of games.)

Posted: June 18, 2015
												The black sheep of the Ace Combat franchise. I was EXTREMELY hyped for this title prior to release. Ace Combat 5 is my favourite game of all time, and I thought this would kick the franchise back into gear again. How foolish.Cons:- The gameplay is nothing like the earlier games, so die hard fans will find almost nothing of value here. - The infamous and bizarre dog-fighting sections play like some on-rails arcade shooter. - There are enforced helicopter sections (admittedly a little fun sometimes), enforced third-person gunner sections (again, sometimes fun) and awful bombing missions with overly-complicated recommended flight paths. - The colour scheme is mostly grey/dark green. - The over all combat is ultimately tedious due to over powered nature of your plane. -  The story is forgettable at best. Nothing compared to the grand and bombastic entries into the Strangereal lore in earlier games.But, for all of that. there is some light to this.Pros:- The port is solid (I'm only judging this after 30 minutes of playing, but nothing has crashed and there are minimal frame drops. Graphics settings are sparse though.)- There are a few jaw-dropping moments, usually involving something to do with ejecting from the craft.- The later missions get extremely intense. The penultimate one is actually fantastic.- The gameplay is solid if you enjoy what it offers. Planes are responsive and destroying enemies is satisfying.- Nagase from AC5 makes an easter egg appearance.- The main theme is Ace Combat-esque, and thrilling for it. Also has a couple of other good tracks, like the free mission hangar OST, which serves as a nice throwback to the PS1 days of the seriesMost of my negativity is just from being so heartbroken that this essentially damned the franchise. I don't want to be an♥♥♥♥♥♥and not recommend it for that reason. If this is your first time playing Ace Combat, give it a whirl.Then get a PS2 and play the better ones

After struggling for a bit with their "optimised control" option (no roll control, just basic WASD style controls that ping back to centre screen with an N64 Goldeneye aiming system feel) I put it into classic which brought back some feeling that this was after all an Ace Combat game, however the dogfight system is nothing like Ace Combat. The whole focused dogfight thing where you lock in is a novel idea, but it feels like they're trying to reward using it, so missiles out of this system seem to miss around 95% of the time. In Squadron Leader you had to be careful that they wouldn't turn out of your range, but as long as you were chasing, a quick doubletap of missiles would bring most enemies down. With this I struggled for quite a while just trying to pin the last plane in a dogfight down for long enough so I could actually fire at him in a straight line or even get in close enough to trigger the dogfight system without him turning off. This would have been less frustrating if the dogfight was one on one, but I had about 10 allied pilots engaged in the same fight that didn't even seem to be attempting to bring him down at all! I think this game would be okay for someone who has no prior experience with the Ace Combat series, but otherwise I'd avoid it.

												TLDR: It's like buying the exact same copy as the PS3 version.I played this a lot on my PS3 and even completed all the trophies and maxed out and dominated (Since you get overpowered skills on max rank) on the multiplayer.Gameplay wise, this game is pretty much entertaining. The new dogfight mode makes you feel like a badass but it also makes the game easier. I like it though but many people seemed disappointed with it. Especially the long time fans of the series. But it's completely optional though. You can even pick between the new and classic controls.Story is okay. It has a typical military action storyline. It entertains you during the cutscenes. It has a COD cutscene feel to it but overall, the story is forgettable. Obviously, it was made to fit the gameplay.Multiplayer is pretty much dead. You can play with your friends though. Coop or other competitive modes but this game's multiplayer shines with a full lobby of people with planes flying around like a swarm of flies killing each other.Now last but not the least, the graphics. I just have to say that this is not a good port but it's not bad either. I was excited to try this game on PC with max settings. But the graphic settings doesn't have a deep graphic customization. There are no advanced graphic settings. That would be cool if it weren't originally made for the PS3 but you can see the lack of texture on this one. It looks like a quick conversion from the PS3 to PC. It's not that bad though, it runs smooth and PS3 graphics still looks good but it could've done better with more textures, more effects and etc. Somehow they didn't take advantage of the superior graphics a PC can offer.

Posted: August 14, 2015
												ACE COMBAT: ASSAULT HORIZONPROS:+Wide selection of modern jet aircraft to choose from, even some older ones like the F-4 Phantom+Customizable paint job option+Simple controls+Decent graphics+Camera angles are handled pretty well+Missions are challenging and fun+Only a few escort missions with most being focused on shooting down aircraft, which is why we play air combat games to begin with+Action follows a story with charactersCONS:-Dogfight Mode is overemphasized, being necessary to take down certain enemies, making the game feel a bit too scripted-Combat is unrealistic as it usually takes 2+ missiles and tons of bullets to shoot down an enemy-Enemies can engage you in DFM and do so endlessly, limiting your maneuverability and pulling you away from whatever you're doing-Allies hardly help you at all except in missions where they are specifically assigned to cover for you-Helicopter missions feel disconnected and don't really seem necessary-Characters are underdeveloped and flat, making it hard to feel anything for them-Story is generic and predictable, rife with cliches -Too many Russian stereotypes-Only the campaign missions are available to choose from in free mission, limiting replayability-Characters never salute commanding officers (what kind of military is this?)FINAL VERDICT:I would rate this game a 6/10. It is a fun pick up and play game, but don't expect realism because you'll be disappointed. I recommend it, but don't pay full price. Full price doesn't feel justified.

												This might be fine for someone who just wants an air combat game to play, but if you're a fan of the older AC titles like AC04 this just isn't for you.Several major elements have been changed for jets: Your machine guns never run out of ammo, and neither do your missiles, they simply have a cooldown period. There's also a new "chase" mechanic which locks you onto an enemy and autopilots you around, making aiming your only concern in a dogfight. It's basically rail shooter mode. Not only is this boring and unchallenging, but it also looks ridiculous as you weave between buildings and oil rigs at mach two. Use of this mechanic is optional against most enemies, but certain VIP targets force you to use it in order to take them down.The helicopter missions come in two flavors: awkwardly controlled attack helo and boring rail shooter transport helo. There are also gunship rail shooter missions straight out of CoD.Overall everything feels very scripted like a CoD game and there isn't a lot of room for stages to play out differently when you replay them. There's no tension because you never run out of ammo, and there's no challenge because of the autopiloting chase system.If you're a long-time AC fan like me you'll probably hate this game. If you still buy CoD games then this is for you.

												I've been a long time Ace Combat fan and I will admit that this game is not all that bad, but I simply cannot recommend it to people who are thinking that they're getting an Ace Combat game when they're purchasing it.1.  The storyI'm well aware that story was never the strong point in Ace Combat games, sure, but they were at least charming enough that you could connect with them.  The story of this game was just too ridiculous to take seriously;  I couldn't help but roll my eyes and think "What.....seriously?" when the "motives" of the main antagonist were revealed (Won't spoil, but it's just STUPID).2.  Helicopter/Gunship missionsThey're kinda neat at first, but the more you do them the more you get to wondering "So when am I getting back into the jet again?".  Ace combat was always based around dogfighting with the best aces around, and these missions just felt completely out of place, like they didn't even belong in an Ace Combat game.3.  DFM (Dog Fighting Mode)It's kinda cool at first.  Makes the game very cinematic and gives you the feeling that you're the badass ace that you're supposed to be; only problem is that they take it WAY too far.  Some parts of the game are literally impossible to complete without it and aren't properly designated so you could be repeating a segment upwards of 10 times without knowing that you HAVE to be in DFM to win.  And I'm sorry, those ace fights where you're literally pumping 10-20 missiles into the back of some "Ace" pilot's plane?  That's not fun, that's just ridiculous.4.  ReplayabilityThere is none.  Sure you could go back and replay missions in the "Free Mission" mode after you unlocked them, but because of all the above problems it's just not FUN to do so.  All those new planes that you unlock after you beat the campaign are basically meaningless because the game forces a set playstyle on you with DFM.Summary/TL;DR:  It was fun for the initial run of the campaign, but not beyond that.  Worth it if you're buying it for the sale, not so much otherwise.

												SINGLEPLAYER Pilot Difficulty REVIEW: I really really wanted to recommend this game. But there just isn't enough going for Assault Horizon for me to do so. The gameplay can get really fun and intense at some parts but in many other it can feel like a drag. Mainly due to the controls and game mechanics. The Dogfighting Mode (DFM) seemed cool at first and to be honest, I really thought it was a nice change for a spinoff game. What I disliked about it is that many of the dogfights (Including the final boss battle) that require DFM require you to wait until you have flown around exploding setpieces before you are allowed to actually damage the target. This can get very annoying and once you discover this you lose that feeling that you are actually using tactics to beat that enemy ace.And then we get to the story by the highly acclaimed millitary writer "Jim DeFelice". Maybe there is something more hidden behind this dull, cliche story but even so, the story itself is a pain to get through. To sum it up: you get betrayed by the Russians who later turn out to just be revolutionaries in a against Russia. Then you work with the Russian loyalists to defeat the coup. Though the bad guy ace escapes with the superweapon to america so you follow him and kill him. The characters are another level of boring too. Most characters are your stereotypical cast: An ace who has a nightmares, a black man who seems interesting if only they dove into his story more, a cocky wingman, and a manly female. All of which are extremely predictable in the cliche things they do.As a player of both AC 4 & 5, I tried to keep the comparisons to a minimum but even so, it is still hard to recommend a game with such potentioal when it's mechanics and story are so lackluster.If you REALLY want to give this game a try. I would say go for it. It's not a terrible game and there are many parts that are really fun and thrilling. But if you are on the fence or expecting the top quality of it's predecessors, I would suggest waiting until the next numerical installment in the series.

Posted: July 27, 2014
												Ignoring its title and separating it from the previous Ace Combat games does little to save it from its own faults. Ace Combat: Assault Horizon takes a step back from the interesting, if not corny world of Strangereal, and plays the Russian/American conflict card. This tired formulaic story is complemented by a downgrade in gameplay. Dogfighting is made simple, and boring, with the introduction of a near-rail-shooter experience that removes the freedom from flight and negates the need for skillful airmanship. It would be acceptable to have a “boss” flight lead require this mechanic, but every flight lead requires that you lock into dogfight mode; even if you land missiles on target, the game ignores the hits and will not progress until you put on your training wheels and go for the ride. The game does include a new diversity of aircraft with the introduction of helicopters and bombers, which if properly executed would nearly save the game, but bomber runs are not particularly fun and the helicopter sections are tedious and awkward. Overall, the game looks great graphically (although the graphical settings are sparse) and gives you a decently realistic flight simulation, but its glaring flaws make it just an okay experience. Personally, I would award 3/5 stars to this game and would recommend picking it up only if it happens to be on sale.

Posted: July 26, 2014
												TLDR:  HOTAS (Saitek X45) won't work with this game.  Probably others as well.  Only playable with a gamepad, and a let-down if you want the classic Ace Combat experience.As a long-time fan of Ace Combat since Ace Combat 4, I can say that this game really is a departure from the old, Ace Combat experience that most fans of the series have come to know and love.  That being said, when I played this game before on my 360, I thought it was still a fun addition to the series.  It could be enjoyable to someone newer to Ace Combat.I got this game while it was available for free one weekend on Steam.  I wanted to see how it would feel controlled by a HOTAS, specifically, a Saitek X45.  I figured this would be simple; after all, Saitek made an Xbox 360 version of the X45 for special editions of Ace Combat 6.  After fumbling around the options screen for 30 minutes, I've determined that it's not possible to use the X45 with this game.The default controls bound my throttle to an axis of movement the X45 isn't capable of.  For X45 users, it was the sliver paddle behind the throttle, usually used for rudder control.  Left and right were both used to yaw left and right, and up and down were used to throttle up and throttle down, except the paddle is only capable of moving left and right, leaving the plane stuck at max throttle.So, why not just bind the throttle control to the X45 throttle?  First I had to learn how to control the menu, because each action I could perform was not listed as a key on the keyboard, but an obscure button from the X45.  Also, the mouse didn't work.  In order to unbind the throttle control, I had to press button 9 on the X45.  After trial-and-error, I learned that button 9 was apparently pressed when I switched the throttle into mode 3 (M3).  Then I selected to choose a key binding, only to have the game immediately tell me that the key I wanted to use was already in use, and needed to be unbound first.  After even more trial-and-error, I just unbound the entire stick and tried to bind the throttle.  That was when I found the source of the problem.  The X45 has several sliders on it that it uses to toggle modes.  The game was interpreting each of them as a button being held down.  The mode switch in particular was either button 9, button 10, or button 11, depending of if it was in position M3, M2, or M1 respectively.  Digital button presses could still be bound by holding the button down when selecting to set a binding, but all analog controls were overridden by the mode switch.And that is where my biggest problem lies.  Why you would put a game about flying a plane on a computer and let that game be incompatible with what is arguably the most recognizable HOTAS available is rediculous.  Even as a port from consoles I would expect a little more effort than what they gave.  I have literally had an easier time getting my X45 to work with games that no-one in their right mind would try to play with an X45 that this one.  I would have been more than happy to buy a poorly-recieved game a second time from NAMCO just for the experience, but now that I know the experience is gone, I'll just stick with my 360 if I really want to play this game again.

Posted: July 27, 2014
												Ignoring its title and separating it from the previous Ace Combat games does little to save it from its own faults. Ace Combat: Assault Horizon takes a step back from the interesting, if not corny world of Strangereal, and plays the Russian/American conflict card. This tired formulaic story is complemented by a downgrade in gameplay. Dogfighting is made simple, and boring, with the introduction of a near-rail-shooter experience that removes the freedom from flight and negates the need for skillful airmanship. It would be acceptable to have a “boss” flight lead require this mechanic, but every flight lead requires that you lock into dogfight mode; even if you land missiles on target, the game ignores the hits and will not progress until you put on your training wheels and go for the ride. The game does include a new diversity of aircraft with the introduction of helicopters and bombers, which if properly executed would nearly save the game, but bomber runs are not particularly fun and the helicopter sections are tedious and awkward. Overall, the game looks great graphically (although the graphical settings are sparse) and gives you a decently realistic flight simulation, but its glaring flaws make it just an okay experience. Personally, I would award 3/5 stars to this game and would recommend picking it up only if it happens to be on sale.

												Ace Combat Assault Horizon - Enhanced Edition is both a fun and entertaining addition to the Ace Combat series.  It is an arcade, nervous, pick and play, flight combat game that I really enjoyed playing.  It is clear that the game makers were trying to mirror the Call of Duty's campaign mode strengths.  In other words, the campaign is explosive, very intense, nervous, and chaotic at moments, as if you are part of a Michael Bay movie.   I personally found it very refreshing and I hope that future sequels will keep this vision.  Finally keep in mind that this is not a hardcore/realistic flight simulator.  Below are my pros and cons :Positives:*  Awesome campaign mode.*  Easy gameplay (with depth at high levels)*  Nervous  (dog)fights.*  Great music and sounds (The japanese voices are outstanding.  The english ones are not so good/bad).*  Pick and play (meaning you don't need to know who is who, or what is what, or what combination of buttons you need to press to make X or Y spell, or when you need to meet Z person at N's location, etc...  Just relax, pick your pad, get in this explosive universe, and enjoy yourself).Negatives:*  The scenario is a very "japanese" take on US politics/conflicts.*  Short campaign (but very intense and fun).Thanks to the developers for the enjoyable experience!Verdict: A-

Posted: November 4, 2015
												"Ace Combat is finally on the PC!!" Is probably what you're thinking when you see this right? Well unfortunately, this isn't the Ace Combat game anyone wanted on PC. Why is that you ask? Well if you've played any AC game pre-AH, then you already know the answer. If you haven't, then allow me to explain why.#1 DFM (Dogfight Mode)DFM is a feature that's supposedly the game's main selling point, which turns the game into an on rails shooter. It's activated when the L and R bumpers are pressed (playing on a 360 controller) when you're in close proximity of an enemy aircraft (green circle flashing). DFM is completely optional to use, except when combating lead targets. Lead targets requires the use of DFM as they're nearly impossible to shoot down without it; even with the CFA-44's EML cannon (OP weapon, more so in AC6). #2 Deviation from the Strangereal world to the real worldStrangereal is the main setting of all the AC games pre-AH. In layman's terms, it's a world with fictitious nations based on their real world equivalents. A lot of people liked the idea of dogfighting in a place that isn't the same ol' boring real world Earth setting. The same people absolutely hated the change of scenery to a real world setting for this game.#3 The StorylineThe abridged version: NATO task force vs a separatist Russian movement armed with a stockpile of bombs with the yield of a nuclear bomb (only they're not). Lamentable, derivative, and boring as some people would say. Honorable Mentions Any of the UH-60 Blackhawk door gunner escort missions, the AC-130 gunner mission, and the Heli gunship missions.Now despite its shortcomings, this game does have its crowning moments of awesome#1 The VisualsThe game itself is absolutely gorgeous. Everything from the environments to the planes themselves. The only downside is that the graphics options are severely limited to AA, Vsync, and resolution. But the sight of an enemy plane exploding into pieces with copious amounts of oil splashing everywhere never gets old. Oh, and the occasional pilot falling out of the cockpit too.#2 The GameplayDespite being heavily reliant on DFM, the game itself is actually really fun to play. Just remember to change the control scheme from optimal to classic. Because on optimal, you can't roll your plane.#3 The PlanesThere is a wide variety of planes to choose from in Assault Horizon; fighters, multirole craft, and even bombers believe it or not. Each and every plane has their own special paint schemes; some are unlocked at the start, some are unlocked when you finish the game, and all are customizable. Oh, and there are Idolmaster themed jets (returns from AC6) as well because Namco.Final Verdict6/10It's not the best Ace Combat game available, but it's worth playing at least once. So yes, I recommend you try it for yourselves.Addendum: If you plan on buying this for the multiplayer, then DON'T. Multiplayer for the most part is a graveyard.

Posted: October 31, 2015
												This game reminds me how much I don't like the Recommend\Don't Recommend system of Steam. This is one of the sad cases where I actually enjoyed a game, quiet a lot even, but am still aware that it isn't much good and is actually not a game to recommend to anyone.I'll start by stating that I didn't play any other installment of Ace Combat and therefore I don't look at this game as a fan of the series, but simply gave this specific installment a try. I'm also not too experienced with flight games in general.Horizon Assault is a very arcadic game in almost every sense of the word.The story is, as you'd expect from this type of games, very predictable, generic, unsurprising, and not that vital for the game.For a moment the game may seem like a flight simulator but it's definitely not, It's good at making you feel AS IF you're flying an aircraft, AS IF you're doing big stuff with the scripted explosions everywhere.And that's actually one of the strong points of the game, it's very good with BOOMING stuff, with making you feel that YOU are booming stuff, and it gives you an addicting sense of action and thrill, although with completely unrealistic mechanics at times (e.g. aircraft "heals" itself automatically while flying), but who cares, it's a video game.The game's soundtrack also adds a LOT to the game, and as one who really cares about music in video games and is giving it a lot of attention, this game has one of the best tracks in video game soundtracks, in my opinion, with a combination of symphonic music with some electronic\rock touches every once in a while. Splendid, really!Unfortunately there are also reasons for you to stay away from Horizon Assault. Controls aren't most comfortable ever… Binding different keys won't help much. It can get confusing at times and at the beginning of the game I felt like quitting because I simply couldn't get hold of this DAMN helicopter. As soon as I got the hang of it, it started to get fun, though, but fun it really different and is a matter of perspective. And many people won't find this game fun at all.The gameplay can get extremely repetitive and frustrating. The developers tried to keep it varied and in a way they succeeded in it, but it's still starting to feel generic and monotonous at times. Another thing which many people would hate is the Dog-Fight System, which is presented as an optional way to hunt your enemies but is actually your only way of getting through this game. And it can be horribly frustrating as well.So, are you going to enjoy this game? That's really a matter of one's taste and expectations.I enjoyed it, mostly, and if you can enjoy some intense action sequences with things getting blown away with dramatic music in the background and some clichéd "saving America" story, it's possible you'd enjoy this as well.It's possible you'd hate it, if that's not your kind …Another note, out of the three times I've tried playing this game in multiplayer mode, I've managed to find other players to play with only once. So, my guess is that the multiplayer scene of Horizon Assault isn't very active. There's also no way to play over LAN, so, I could be wrong but I believe Horizon Assault pretty much leaves you with solely the single player missions. You should keep that in mind.

What I got was a game that felt like it had been "CODified" so to speak. The campaign in Ace Combat games has always had an anmazing story with great characters. This just felt like call of duty but with planes instead, using re-hashed cliches and ideas of having the russians be the bad guys and installing parts like the helicopter gunner which does not belong in this game. I hated it the more I played, very little that i did. The whole system of the close-range assualt system was just complete garbage. It adds no value to the game, just more ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t they pile on to give it a "cinematic" feel. The "dramatic realistic storyline" was another insult as well. Something that has been done time and again, its just a lazy♥♥♥♥♥♥story they cobbled together to try and have some sort of setting made with no effort for the game. All the intense moments in Shattered Skies and Unsung War were amazing, like when Nagase was in danger as her plane was going down, but then she ends up rescuing fellow soldiers and taking some enemies hostage right after ejecting like a hardass; or you are protecting a rocket that needs to deliver a ♥♥♥♥ing laser to a low orbit plane to give you an edge in the war, or when you have to shoot down that same plane when the enemy takes it. All of the banter between the pilots and command was really funny, dramatic, and had actual emotion to it. Unique, colorful, and masterpieces of missions and storytelling. This entire game is a stain and shameful mark upon the legacy and awe left by those earlier games, not fit to share the title of Ace Combat. If I could I would wipe this game from my library just so I dont have to look at such a pile of excrement. Do not buy this game if you have played the previous masterpieces. If your a COD fanboy who likes campaigns that only take a few hours to complete, and the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t story cliches time and time again, this is right up your alley.

Posted: April 11, 2014
												AC:AH handles like the usual Ace Combat formula with the bombast and overzealous scripting of the latest Call of Duty games thrown in. Numerous times the game uses it's on-rails Dogfight Mode (DFM) or it's even more restrictive cousin Airstrike Mode to force the player to fly under -that- collapsing smokestack or -that- inexplicable jumbo jet, completely irrespective of the direction or location in which it was initiated. Allies/enemies vanish and materialise as the mission scripting decrees, or are completely invulnrable until they become a later mission objective. The DFM is also lacking in options for the player; you can just hold MG and accelerate and watch the pretty colours.The (apparently) mandatory AC-130 level, the door gunner sections and the helicopter gunship bits, I'm afraid I can't speak fairly on them. Generally I slogged through them until I got my jet back, and certainly wasn't taking notes, other than to say the ground /building textures weren't designed for hovering that close to them.The story is, well, the typical "US saves the world from someone who wants specifically to attack the US" fare we've seen everywhere since CoD 4. The comms chatter and recurring callsigns that has always made allies seem interesting is still there, but sparser and sandwiched in between asking for help and spontaneous bravado. The sense of edging along with a ground war is missing from the AC formula too - your team can hop between continent as if on an extended holiday, and the sense of bring under threat suffers. I didn't feel much attachment to the callsign either; Warwolf's leader is no Mobius One. As good as the real-world setting is, I feel Strangereal is a better setting for these games.I'm giving it a negative rating, but that's not to say a bad game. The combat is wonderfully involving in its freeform state, with an excellently majestic soundtrack (Kieki Kobayashi et al doing what they do best), a great selection of planes and enough variation in weapon loadouts / handling / mission objectives to keep it fresh. There's some character to all four members of your flight, as well as the allied squadrons and land-dwelling elements, and even the traditional objective-dispensing AWACS operator has some colour to him.In summary, what's good is most of the parts I liked from AC's 4 and 6 (you can even get the Estovakian fictional superplane from AC6, in original Strigon Squadron colours), and the parts i disliked were clearly taken wholesale from CoD and grafted around the Ace Combat experience. People looking to get the thrill arcade digfighters give would do well to look at JASF (interesting story idea there) or look to play Fires of Liberation.

												Good storyline to this game, a bit too arcadey for my liking but if you can look passed the unrealistic flight physics and the unordinate amount of missiles you can carry it can be very fun. I love the dogfight mode which feels really epic especially when dipping in between buildings and landmarks (albeit very ridiculous flight physics). A game like this, I prefer to put myself in cockpit view to get fully immersed into the role. Unfortunately this games cockpit mode doesnt feel quite immersive, it seems like "the wrong way to play" and as such I spent most of my time playing in Third person which to it's credit, looks amazing. The graphics on the explosions in my opinion are stunning. It's a great flight combat game, but not a simulator. For me, a better flight combat experience would put all characters in realistic serious handicapped state i.e. I'd rather fight 6 Ace Pilots with limited missiles and bullets than 60 idiot pilots armed with a million missiles. Overall however this game is great, a great step into the kind of flight game I like & want to see more of. Using cutscenes based on the ground and air to great effect to build up the empathy for the characters is a great touch (no longer is my wingman a faceless friend, now you get to see him interacting with my character on the ground.)Great game. If only it was less arcadey it'd be even better.

Posted: July 25, 2014
												It's a little bit hard reccomending this game, since the game has many good and bad points. The game is not a flight simulator, and tends to be an arcade flight game, where most of the time all you need to do is press space bar while you crosshair is red. With beautiful graphics, some skippable CGs and an nice soundtrack during fights, it can be a very fun game.My first sensation while playing the game was that it was a lot flashy, and designed to be something easy for your free time, and it can be enjoyable, but with times get a little boring and repetitive. When you are too close from the ground, too close to the map end or in DFM (Dogfight Mode), almost all of the controls are taken from you to make the game easier to new players. But sometimes, it gets too easy, and during chopper flights you almost only have to hold the two mouse buttons and A/D to kill everything.If you are looking for a game where the first challenge starts in getting familiar with the controls to have complete control over the aircraft, this game is far from it. This game has a feel of being targeted to more casual players, not exactly excluding hadcore gamers, but the major part of the game is made to be fun, not challenging.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												I've never played the older AC games (I don't have a gaming console), and granted I got this game while it was on sale (I had my eyes on this game for a while, and was waiting for a sale), but I'll say this: Sometimes companies decide to take a different approach to their franchises for a lot of different reasons, and it's either you'll love them or hate them for doing it. From the reviews of the game by fans of the old AC games I've read, many are absolutely appalled by it. I don't think they're wrong - they're seeing a franchise they've been with for a very long time change into something they're not used to. (I had the same feeling when the Total War franchise decided to go into Warhammer, for example, and I felt the same disappointment, too.)But that's not to say those fans are right either. Project Aces was obviously trying to test out something new, and I think it's quite brave of them to have given it a try (after recovering from the initial disappointment, I feel the same of the Total War franchise now).Now, for those that are still deciding whether to buy the game or not, here's the best way I can put it:(1) DFM takes quite a bit of getting used to, but it'll feel rewarding when you tail another fighter and gun them down.(2) It's nothing like the old AC games (from what I can judge from the Let's Plays I've seen people play), but it's an interesting spin on the genre.(3) If you don't like the campaign, see the story as a massive tutorial that teaches you what you'll need to know to be effective in multiplayer.(4) Judging from the mechanics, the game was originally designed with multiplayer as more a core feature than single player.In the end, a game's a game - some of them we love, others not so much. The franchise titles represent something significant for some people, but not so much for others. I understand those grieving for what AC's become, but I'm personally happy that there's an AC game on PC, and agree with those that enjoy the game for what it is.

Posted: July 8, 2014
												Let me state I've already played and completed this game when it initially came out on the xbox 360. I've always been an ace combat fan so I'll admit to some bias in that regard, along with a love of military aircraft in general. That said, this itiration of the Ace Combat series, while fun, full of adrenaline, and still top notch in visual quality as you'd expect, I still felt the new Dog Fighting mechanic took away from some of the imersion. In previous titles, dog fighting was as you'd imagine, difficult. Trying to follow your target while staying in range for your main gun and leading the target so you actually hit. While at the same time making sure you did not crash into anything. This, obviously takes some skill and practice, which I felt was a good challenge to the game.Assault Horizon however takes the burden of piloting and has you focus more on the target. Now it's a matter of making sure your crosshair is on target for your main gun or missles (whichever you prefer) and the plane is essentially on auto pilot after the target. You can change your pitch and angle, sure, but you are certainly only following the target aircraft.This was more a design decision to add cinematic fluff than anything else. That hollywood sequence of flying just underneath a crane while at Mach 2 is undeniably impressive and enjoyable for most. But after repeated intervals, it begins to feel cheapened. This is certainly a good game for those new to the flight combat sim, or new to Ace Combat in general to get a feel for series. While I wish they kept the old dog fighting mechanics in this, it does allow for a lot of 'wow' moments when you do pull them off.

												If you are a fan of the Ace Combat games like AC04, don't buy this one. Special weapons have been nerfed, your ability to be a pilot is a lot less necessary. Almost to the point where if you can keep your plane from crashing into the ground, you can do whatever you want in this one. This makes your flying skill almost irrelevant. DFM is a joke, essentially is an autopilot that follows enemy planes in an on-the-rails path. As long as you keep your plane pointing vaguely in the same direction as your target, you won't lose it. On top of that, there are a few enemies that are invincible unless you enter DFM with them.In previous titles, if you got hit by AA weaponry whether it was flak, guns, SAMs, or air to air missiles, you kept the damage you recieved unless you returned to base for repairs. Not this one. So long as you don't take damage for about 10 seconds, any damage that has been done to your plane will be repaired immediately. Another aspect that removes piloting skill from the game.If you want an aerial combat game that feels like you are a fighter pilot, don't get Ace Combat: Assault Horizon. Dust off your old Playstation 2, and play Ace Combat 04: Shattered Skies.

												Before you dive into the Steam reviews, please consider looking at IGN's review of it; it's short, to-the-point, and is UNBIASED.A lot of the hate comes from changes from previous games. Helicopters, a "Dog fight mode" (close range dog fight) and a different setting are all changes I can think of off the top of my head. To die-hards of old Ace Combat, these changes are probably going to drive you nuts (*cough cough* steam reviews *cough cough*) but if you have an open mind, understand that the developers are HUMAN BEINGS and not some perfect-game-making-robots, you'll enjoy yourself.I found the game really fun, beautiful, and rather thrilling in some parts. The dog fight mode (called DFM in the game) was really an adrenaline rush at parts. Particularly near the end, when things ramp up. The helicopter missions were very fun for me (though the gun controls were a small bit clunky). The story, while kind of cliche, is still worth paying attention to in my opinion. The graphics are beautiful (you can tell the developers put some work into properly porting it to PC :D )Some of the missions do seem to drag on, and I feel like the developers put more focus on their new mechanics (e.g., DFM) than they should have, but hey, why hold that against them? It's pretty hard to guess the perfect way to implement a brand new mechanic on the first try.It took me about 8 hours to beat the campaign on an easier difficulty.All-around a good game. :)TL;DRWorth the $20 if you plan on playing multiplayer (not sure if anyone plays it, I haven't looked), maybe closer to $15 or $10 if you plan on only playing campaign. Take the Steam reviews for this game with a grain of salt; a lot of them just really don't like the changes.P.S.Sorry if some of the review doesn't make sense; I'm writing this really late at night XD

Posted: June 26, 2016
												**Disclaimers**I have played this game in full on the Xbox 360 I have also played Ace Combats 4, 5, Zero, 6, and X (the PSP one) Now, the review.As a game, Ace Combat:Assault Horizon gets my reccomendation. As an Ace Combat game, It does not. Thats the short of it.  I'm reccomending this game, but in a way also not reccomending it. At a sale price of $5, a newcomer could very well get his or her monies worth out of the title. But a veteran of the series will likely be dissappointed with it. I really wish Steam had a third reccomendation option of "Maybe", because this game would fit right into that. As an arcade flight simulator, this game is good. It beats the hell out of HAWX, that much I'll support. If you're just looking for a quick action/war game, then this might be right up your alley. But if you're fan of the other games in the series, this game is a complete letdown. The staples of the other games, from the anti-war themes, epic boss battles with fictional super weapons and the fictional world of Strangereal are all put to the side. In its place are helicoper segments, both on and off rails, bomber missions, the typical "Russians are the bad guys" story with somewhat strong 'murica themes, and the new "Dogfight Mode" (DFM), which dumbs down fights to this hybrid on rails mini-game. None of these things are bad for other games, but for Ace Combat it is a real let down.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												I've never played the older AC games (I don't have a gaming console), and granted I got this game while it was on sale (I had my eyes on this game for a while, and was waiting for a sale), but I'll say this: Sometimes companies decide to take a different approach to their franchises for a lot of different reasons, and it's either you'll love them or hate them for doing it. From the reviews of the game by fans of the old AC games I've read, many are absolutely appalled by it. I don't think they're wrong - they're seeing a franchise they've been with for a very long time change into something they're not used to. (I had the same feeling when the Total War franchise decided to go into Warhammer, for example, and I felt the same disappointment, too.)But that's not to say those fans are right either. Project Aces was obviously trying to test out something new, and I think it's quite brave of them to have given it a try (after recovering from the initial disappointment, I feel the same of the Total War franchise now).Now, for those that are still deciding whether to buy the game or not, here's the best way I can put it:(1) DFM takes quite a bit of getting used to, but it'll feel rewarding when you tail another fighter and gun them down.(2) It's nothing like the old AC games (from what I can judge from the Let's Plays I've seen people play), but it's an interesting spin on the genre.(3) If you don't like the campaign, see the story as a massive tutorial that teaches you what you'll need to know to be effective in multiplayer.(4) Judging from the mechanics, the game was originally designed with multiplayer as more a core feature than single player.In the end, a game's a game - some of them we love, others not so much. The franchise titles represent something significant for some people, but not so much for others. I understand those grieving for what AC's become, but I'm personally happy that there's an AC game on PC, and agree with those that enjoy the game for what it is.

Posted: October 10, 2016
												I'm a long time Ace Combat fan, and while this game isn't as amazing as the previous games (like Ace Combat 6, or 2.) the game has its charm, and at its core it is still an Ace Combat game. For the most part, you can play without ever initiating DSM mode yourself. Though, enemies can do it to you, it isn't actually that bad, and you can even escape it just by stalling or speeding away. The DSM mode isn't terrible, and while it is a bit goofy, it's fun. The damage is interesting, especially when you see a pilot fall out of his plane because the cockpit seperates. The story, is not that interesting. But it's not terrible, again, nothing about this game is actually bad. It's just not what people expected from an Ace Combat game.You need to do the controls fix, this is a must. Playing with your mouse is incredible. The feature is broken upon install because of the Windows Live remover patch.

Posted: September 18, 2016
												It's an okay game. A bad Ace Combat game. Performance wise it runs fine, graphics are all right though use a down right horrible motion blur/heat haze system and audio is, well to think of it I never noticed it. So that's good and bad. I recall no standout moments audio wise nor any glarring WTF sound effects. The game is mediocre in every sense of the word. I feel like none of my allies ever kill a single enemy. Literally a dozen friendlies and I'll have to take out every single one of the 20 plus enemies. It takes literally 30-45 minutes sometimes to beat a mission of simple enemy waves. I'm also not too fond of the new "zoom in up close to semi-scripted sequences" which you can trigger when within like 1000 meters of the enemy. It's lame and almost the only reliable way to take out enemies otherwise. Especially when those sequences  appear to be the only time the enemy hits ground targets outside of scripted triggers. Otherwise it's a solid, decent arcady aerial combat game. Oh, and the Apache helicopter controls just plain, flat out suck. Having to aim wiht your mouse, yet push mouse all the way to the edge of the screen and hold to rotate the chopper. It's ludicrous. There are quite a number of better dogfighting games. A lot if you drift to realistic, simulator side of it. Hell, there are better Ace Combat games. They're older and only on PS2 (one was on 360 I think, it was better than average) but they're still better.
